title: meghan markle gets henna tattoo
story: NewsMeghan Markle gets henna tattoo to bring luck for the baby on Morocco tourThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex touched down in Asni in the Atlas Mountains region to visit a centre helping young women get a secondary educationShareCommentsByRussell MyersMatt Leclere:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video harry-meghan-arrive-crowds-greet-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest Royal Family stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle has received a henna tattoo celebrating her pregnancy during a visit to Moroccos high Atlas Mountains region. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex touched down in Asni by helicopter to meet young women getting a secondary education thanks to the efforts of a British entrepreneur. In brilliant winter sunshine Harry and Meghan were welcomed to the town of Asni by pupils being taught at a boarding house run by the Moroccan NGO Education For All, founded by Michael McHugo.Resident Samira Ouaadi, , became Meghan ’s henna artist.She has lived there for six years and painted the flower on Meghan’s right hand and forearm to mark her pregnancy which is considered a blessing.  The henna is tradition in Morocco during the seventh month of pregnancy to celebrate the health of the mother and baby. Meghan, , sat patiently for three minutes while a flower pattern was painted on her left hand. When it was finished she said said it was really lovely before showing it off to Prince Harry.   Samira said: “It is a traditional practice for pregnant women in Morocco. It is to bring luck for the baby.” The tattoo, made from a dye from the henna plant, will stay for around two weeks before it fades. It is made from a brown paste by mashing and pulping the plants bark. A traditional song and drums were performed by the girls when the couple arrived at the school.Theyve dressed casually for the trip with Meghan sporting a navy jacket and black trousers and black pumps. Prince Harry dressed down for the visit too with a light grey jumper, pink shirt, casual trousers and tan boots.Inside the classrooms most of the girls were fluent only in French. But Meghan seemed more at ease than her Eton educated husband.   She asked in French: “Qu’est-ce que tu veux etre quand tu quittes l’eacutecole  . She also asked: “Vous voulez aller agrave l’universiteacute  . The answers impressed Meghan who replied saying they wanted to be teachers, engineers and doctors. “It’s so impressive that so many of the girls are studying maths and physics and the sciences, she said to Harry. Meghan was amazed about the girls coming back to the school to inspire others calling it a big family”. The duchess also asked in Frenchshe could enter the girls bedrooms, “On peut renter.” She also used a smattering of French words such as “parfait .   Eton College educated Harry, who has delivered speeches in French, was less confident. “Do you speak English  I don’t speak much French,” he said. He added “very good singing” and asked what their lives would be like without the opportunity the school offers them. Khadija ait Talat, , “We have been learning about the duchess. She is a beautul lady. l told her I will be a science teacher and she seemed very impressed.” Meghan said: “It is really good to see that science is promoted among girls. Lata Berrkhouch described Meghan as beautul and inspiring adding Prince Harry had wished her luck for her exams. Nawal ait Idmou, , said: “They both seemed very impressed by what was happening at our school.” At the end of the engagement Meghan and Harry spotted two local girls who were waiting for them outside.  SistersRania and Rayhana Minejem, five and two, who are half British and half Moroccan, told the Duchess of Sussex they “loved” the henna tattoo she had just had done moments earlier. Meghan said: “Hi girls, how are you  thanks for waiting to see us.” Their mum ClareMcCaugey said: “It was so lovely Meghan and Harry stopped to speak to the girls. “I wanted them to come as they are half Moroccan and half British becausethey live in Morocco they know about their British side but I wanted them to celebrate their British side as well.” The girls’ grandad Russell McCaugey, , from Bangor, Northern Ireland, jokingly called out to Harry saying: “No grand slam this year Harry!” - after England lost to Wales in the rugby Six Nations yesterday. Harry smiled and called back: “I don’t think they’ll be one for anyone this year.” Holding Union and Morocco flags the teenage girls smiled as their guests arrived from the capital Rabat by helicopter.  Students living in rural areas of Morocco often have to travel long distances to their nearest secondary school.Many are also overcrowded with timetables staggered meaning there are large gaps in the day.It means they frequently miss out on their schooling altogether as parents decide to keep them at home over fears of where they will be during the day. Meghan and Harry walked along a line of waiting teenagers and following local custom touched a hand to their heart each time they shook the hand of a student. The duke asked one pupil Is this the best school in Morocco  and as they were taken inside the boarding house he put his hand reassuringly on the back of his heavily pregnant we. Around % of women and girls in Morocco are illiterate and the programme helps to improve education and equality for women. The royal couple are in the town learning about the foundation set up by Mr McHugo, who will be presented with an MBE later in the visit by Prince Harry.   Mr McHugo set up the programme in  and now helps  girls and young women in five houses in the town, with a sixth due to be built this year. The visit is at the request of the British government and is the second visit to the north African country in the last eight years. Harry’s father, Prince Charles, visited in  while the Queen attended in . The couple will head to another school to watch pupils playing football before meeting Mr McHugo - who was named in the New Years Honours List for services to improving gender equality in education in Morocco.This evening the royals will be hosted at a reception by the British Ambassador, Thomas Reilly whose excitable Twitter posts have won him a legion of royal fans after he posted pictures about wearing Union Jack socks.

story: NewsOne of UKs most popular dogs and inspiration for Monopoly piece at riskThe Scottish terrier is one of the most celebrated dog breeds in the UK, and even had a Monopoly piece to its nameShareCommentsByLaura ForsythSam Gelder:,  FEB NewsThe Scottish terrier - one of the UKs most popular dogs is now at risk "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email One of Britains most popular breeds of dog is now at risk as its population has declined.The Scottish terrier is falling out of fashion, according to new figures from The Kennel Club.In the past five years, the number of Scotties being registered has declined by %.Now the dog welfare organisation has now placed it on its at watch list because the number of puppy registrations last year fell  below the  threshold. Over the years, Scotties have been used to advertise products such as Radley handbags and shortbread. However it is now one of many native British breeds at risk as their popularity declines and demand increases for new breeds such as the French Bulldog - now the UKs most popular dog. Of the  native breeds,  are now deemed vulnerable, with nine more at watch, and The Kennel Club has launched a poundsavebritishdogbreeds campaign to reverse the decline.   Those now classed as vulnerable, meaning they have fewer than  new registrations in a year, include the bearded collie and the Irish wolfhound. Kennel Club secretary Caroline Kisko said: There were just  vulnerable breeds and seven at watch a decade ago. There are now another six breeds either vulnerable or at watch and we could lose even more of our most iconic and historic native dog breedspeople dont look beyond the most obvious choices - such as the increasingly popular French Bulldog - and start to explore the huge ersity of breeds were lucky enough to have in this country.   Til Tovey, secretary of the Scottish Terrier Club of England, added: It is so sad to see this wonderful and well-recognised breed, which is affectionate, loyal and intelligent, steadily decline in popularity as more fashionable choices take over. The Scottish Terrier is a great breed for those who want a small companion dog with plenty of character and an independent streak, and have time to train them consistently. Scotties are brimming with personality so sometimes can be a little stubborn! It would be very sad to no longer see this historic and much-loved breed in our streets and parks in a few generations time.

title: shock state armed forces homes
story: NewsShock state of Armed Forces homes revealed - with rats, mould and dirty waterEXCLUSIVE: Squalid homes on army bases have sparked , complaints and reports of everything from leaks to poisonous waterShareCommentsBySean RaymentAlan Selby:,  FEB NewsLiberty Waddle, , suffered when she tried to take a bath "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe squalid state of the homes many Armed Forces shyfamilies are forced to live in is shockingly laid bare shytoday. Some of the houses and flats on service bases are plagued by rats and riddled with leaks. As well as mould, there are even cases of poisonous water. Some families have had to wait weeks for hot water, heating and shycooking shyfacilities. Others have complained about rats and mould in bedrooms which has made young children ill. The private company hired by the Ministry of Defence to maintain the properties, Amey, has had,complaints in three years over the appalling shyconditions – up to , each month.   More than , families are demanding cash from Amey, who look after , armed forces home in the UK.Problems are so bad that a Facebook group called Victims of Amey has , members.Liberty Waddle, , who lives on Bulford Camp in Wiltshire, pays pound a month for the two-bed end of shyterrace she moved into with her husband, a lance-corporal in the Royal Signals. She said: “Water leaks through the ceiling when I have a bath. “The fuse box is broken but they’re refusing to come out and fix it. It keeps blowing all the time. “We didn’t have to have the heating on when we moved in because it was summer. When it got to winter I tried to put the heating on and it didn’t actually work. “I battled with them for four months to get it fixed, but all they gave me was six nights in a hotel.   “While I was in a hotel they said they’d fixed it and flushed the system. I moved back in and the water was freezing cold. “I had a job interview the next day, and the water was coming out bright green. “I rang them so many times and they said ‘If it’s warm enough just get in it.’ I had to get straight out. My skin was burning. I had a rash.” Libby says an shyengineer who came to the property told her the water was contaminated with antreeze. She added: “I’d been drinking it, bathing in it and giving it to my dog. I had bronchitis, two chest infections and a pelvic infection from the shycontaminated water.” Lucie Coleman, who is married to Welsh Guards bandsman Ben Coleman, posted pictures on Facebook of a leaking ceiling in her home which Amey had failed to fix. They have a -month-old child. Mrs Coleman, who is a member of the Victims group, wrote: “Want to know the truth on the standards of military housing  This is what Amey deems acceptable for military families to live in. This is how they treat those that serve your country. “The incompetence of their service is beyond a joke.”   The House of Commons Public Accounts Committee delivered a withering blast at the company’s shy“totally unacceptable” performance. The MPs on the committee said service families were suffering mouldy, damp and unheated homes and experiencing rat shyinfestations. They found there were , shycomplaints over three years. General Lord Richard Dannatt, the former head of the Army, said the lack of good housing could even shydamage the mental health of troops and their families. He told the Sunday People: “I am not convinced that enough is being spent on personnel matters such as good housing and barrack shymaintenance. I fear the tightness of the MoD budget is beginning to have a major negative effect.“ CarillionAmey was awarded a pound.billion contract in  to shymaintain , service quarters shybecause their bid was the lowest. They changed their name to Amey after outsourcing giant Carillion went bust. The MoD said: “We continue to work closely with Amey to further improve accommodation services. “In the current financial year we will spend poundmillion.” A spokesman for Amey said: “Amey took on the contract to maintain shyservice family accommodation in January . “Since then, service levels have improved signicantly and the volume of complaints we have received each month has continued to fall.”

title: slimming world turns 50 inspiring
story: NewsSlimming World turns : Inspiring weight loss stories from last five decadesSince , Slimming World has helped thousands of Brits feel healthier and happier — here are five of their storiesShareCommentsByKevin Donald:,  FEB News"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs Slimming World turns , we speak to five people whose inspiring stories span the past five decades..... sIve been a member since the beginning Betty Oldknow, , is a Slimming World consultant. She lives in Alfreton, Derbyshire, with her husband, Arnold.As my sister Jessie and I walked into the scout hut in , we weren’t sure what to expect. The whole concept of a slimming group was new. With a friend’s wedding approaching, both of us were feeling frumpy and thought it was worth finding out more. We’d already tried to lose weight by ourselves, without much luck. So we joined the room full of people, feeling slightly nervous.  But as I listened to our welcoming consultant Margaret explain her slimming philosophy, I started to think my two shillings and sixpence weekly fee — around p in today’s money — was going to be a good investment. Going to group became a real highlight of my week, with lots of friends laughing together. And we soon started losing weight.  We learnt a lot about food and how to fill up on the ingredients best for weight loss. I lost st, felt full of confidence at the wedding, and took up Margaret’s offer to take over a group. My greatest worry on joining was I might have to give up our weekend takeaway, but I didn’t need to. Before I joined, for three weeks, I’d driven to the venue, parked up, then driven home again. Once I finally got inside, experienced the atmosphere and found the plan would fit with our family tradition, I wished I’d gone sooner. It took me six months to lose four stone in , encouraged by my group and mum, Margaret, who was always the first to hear about my weight loss.  I trained to be a consultant myself and, with mum looking out for me, I kept the weight off as I embarked on my new career. In , mum passed away suddenly at . I developed fibromyalgia, a long-term condition causing pain all over my body, and felt at my lowest ebb.  But in , Rob and I decided to start a new business — a vape shop. I wasn’t sure a young ld like me would fit in, but I quickly felt at home and found inspiration surrounded by other people who all had the same goal. Since losing over six stone, I feel % better. title: worried mum begs doctors give
story: NewsWorried mum begs doctors to give -stone son gastric bypass at  years oldEXCLUSIVE: Donna Rawlins is convinced her son should have a £, gastric bypass on the NHS after she had one doneShareCommentsByGeraldine McKelvieJack Falber:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDonna Rawlins says she thinks her st son Ben should have a gastric bypass like she did "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMum Donna Rawlins blames herself for letting her -year-old son Ben become obese. At  stone, three pounds, he is more than twice the average weight for his age after scoffing mountains of junk food. Now his mum is begging doctors to give him a pound, NHS gastric bypass. That is because Donna — who herself once weighed  stone — had the same operation last year. The -year-old ambulance worker said the procedure helped her to shed st and she now weighs less than her son. “People might criticise me for wanting to put my child through major surgery but I know from my own experience that it will change his le,” she said. During the procedure, the top part of the stomach is joined to the small intestine, so you feel fuller soon and you don’t absorb as many calories through food.   Ben, who is ft in tall, is bullied over his weight and lacks the willpower to diet. He said: “The bullying makes me feel bad. I want a gastric bypass like my mum. “Even though it would take a while to recover, I think it would be worth it and I could go on my bike with my friends.” Donna, from Havant, Hants, said: “I’ve broken down in tears in the doctor’s surgery because he really needs help. “A gastric bypass is major surgery but will be worth it. “Willpower is a big problem with Ben. He’s asked for slimming shakes but they’ll leave him hungry and he’ll give up. “If I could turn back time, I wouldn’t have let him eat so much junk. “I always apologise to him for letting him become the way he is as I blame myself.   “I’ve tried to push him into rugby and football but he would rather come home and play the Xbox.” Ben ate normally until he was four when Donna split with his dad and he started to have tantrumsshe didn’t ply him with chips, pasta and biscuits. “He would lob the plate across the roomhe didn’t like what was on there,” she said. “He was a chicken nugget machine. I would only give him about four at first. As he got older, his appetite would increase and he was always saying he was hungry. “I tried giving him smaller portions but half an hour later, he’d be raiding the cupboards for biscuits. I do wish I hadn’t given in now.”   She added: “I’ve been told I need to cut things down and be strict with him but he has behavioural issues and I need a house left standing. “I can’t constantly be decorating because he is lobbing a plate across the room. “He has all the signs of ADHD including poor concentration but he’s never been diagnosed. “I’m always being told it’s a parenting issue. I ask myselfI’m a bad parent. But I always come down on him like a ton of bricks over right and wrong.” Bullies teased Ben when they saw his mum at the school gates. Donna explained: “Ben was coming home upset as he was being taunted. People would say, ‘You are getting as fat as your mum’.   “It would destroy me. Some nights, I’d sit here in tears but I would use food as a comfort and he picked up on it. She could munch her way through  bags of crisps after a huge helping of pasta and chips. “I would watch telly nibbling crisps to try to make myself feel happier and he’d say, ‘You do it mum, why can’t I ’” Donna was  stone by the time she was  — and being bullied made her eat more. She said: “I was always called ‘fat cow’ walking down the road, and told boys would never have me because I’m fat. “I was terrible for eating in secret. I’d stuff my face silly at mates’ houses so my mum wouldn’t know.” At , when she fell pregnant with Ben, she was so heavy her st scales couldn’t hold her weight. Donna tried the Atkins Diet, which saw her shed st, but doctors warned it was affecting her kidneys.   She said: “I starved myself for a week once because I was so sick of Ben being bullied but I had no energy and I was no good for him. Stuck at st, she asked seven doctors to refer her for a gastric bypass before she was finally accepted last April. The op has left her feeling “ecstatic”. “I woke up from the operation and, for the first time ever, I had no interest in food,” she said. “The weight started falling off. People I’ve known for years don’t recognise me in the street. “Now, I’m stuffedI eat a Weetabix so I know it would be a godsend for Ben. I’ve been asking doctors to give him the operation for two years. “I don’t want him getting diabetes, or heart disease. But most of all I just don’t want him to have the miserable le I had for years.” Ben wants to join the police or the army when he leaves school and Donna believes the op would encourage him to be more active. She said: “He can’t join the police or the armyhe can’t run. “If I can get him down weight wise, he will enjoy sport more and won’t have kids taking the mickey and running round the pitch like a lump of lard. “I still give him treats, like a bag of popcorn on a Friday night, but I ration them.”   On a typical day, Ben’s breakfast is Weetabix, toast and scrambled eggs. Lunch is a ham sandwich and dinner spaghetti bolognese or pasta bake with chips. He no longer snacks through ten biscuits, a bowl of ice cream and a big bag of microwave popcorn each day. Tam Fry, from the National Obesity Forum, said the NHS gave children weight loss surgery onlytheir conditions were le threatening. “The child’s mum has done very well to lose this weight but it is not a good idea for the child to have bariatric surgery,” he said. “A child is still growing andyou have a gastric bypass you are severely limiting the food which that child needs in order to grow. “People might say it’s better to be thin and small but the body should be allowed to grow to its full, natural size. “The mother should hang off for a few years, all the time doing her utmost to keep him off the junk food he has been eating. “He will also need psychiatric counselling because the child has eaten too much fast food all of his le and will have a yearning to continue after a gastric bypass. “That will be ruinous because it might upset the bypass. He is not of an age to appreciate how crucial it is that he should amend his lestyle. “It’s less likely he’ll have the mental capacity to moderate his eating practices.”   Kids getting fat busting surgery at  Obese children as young as  are undergoing weight-loss surgery on the NHS. Latest stats from NHS Digital show  overweight youngsters under the age of  were operated on at hospitals in England in the three years to April . Among them were two -year-olds, five aged  and seven aged . The ops, called bariatric surgery, involve reducing stomach size, bypassing it or installing gastric bands so people eat less. A record ,-plus kids aged  to  are severely obese, one in , according to Public Health England. Tam Fry, spokesman for the National Obesity Forum, said: “There are children who are so fat that when they go to bed they roll over and lie on their airways and suffocate. “It is obese kids with le-threatening conditions like this who are having bariatric surgery. “Normally children of that age will not be given bariatric surgery because they are still growing. But in emergency cases, it does happen.”

title: womans nose rebuilt forehead after
story: NewsWomans nose rebuilt from forehead after she found tumour inside harmless spotWARNING, GRAPHIC CONTENT: Cindy Biddle reveals shocking pictures of her recovery from le-changing surgeryShareByTim Wyatt:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsToday, Cindys scars are almost entirely healed "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who survived skin cancer has revealed how doctors had to reconstruct her face after finding a tumour in what looked like a harmless spot. School teacher Cindy Biddle underwent major surgery to remove the skin cancer which was lodged inside her nose. Although the surgeons were able to remove the danger, they had to remove part of the -year-olds nostril and rebuild it using skin from her forehead. The reconstruction left her with huge swelling disfiguring her face while it healed, but Cindy. from Florida, said she refused to let people stare. My scars were pretty jarring, but there’s no way I was going to hide away. “If I caught anyone giving me an unwarranted stare, I told it to them straight, she said.   One time, I turned around on a group of guys walking behind me and they jumped back with a look of disgust. It reduced me to tears, and when I saw them again the day after, they were all laughing. “This time, I kept my cool and told them: ‘Don’t act like jerks. It’s obvious I’ve had surgery.’ “They turned tail and ran.” Today the teachers scars are almost totally healed, but she - and doctors - almost missed the cancer entirely.   The only visible sign of the tumour growing inside her face was a tiny sore, which looked just like a spot that would not heal. Cindy tried picking at it and moisturising, and was even prescribed an antibiotic cream by her doctor, but it would not get better. It was only identied as basal cell carcinoma - a skin cancer is mostly caused by too much exposure to the ultraviolet rays from the sun - by accident.The history teacher had gone to a walk-in clinic because she had a bad migraine , when the new doctor spotted the spot on her nose and immediately referred to a specialist. Cindy said she had no idea spending too much time outdoors could have given her cancer. I’d been working as a bar tender at a local Mexican place and had spent a fair amount of time in the sun and on the beach. “Growing up, no one gave a second thought to sun protection and I spent a lot of my childhood outside in the sunshine. “I was told the cancer had probably been growing for decades, possibly since I was  years old.” When she did go under the kne to remove the tumour, her husband Jonathan had to leave the room he was so shocked by the size of the growth.   Doctors then stretched her cheek skin to cover the hole and built her a new left nostril with skin from her forehead. Despite her shocking new appearance, Cindy said there was no alternative. This was something I had to do, because otherwise the cancer was literally going to eat my face off. I could have lost an eye or my entire nose.” She charted her recovery from the surgery with photos as the swelling gradually went down and her face ed to normal. Today, she is focusing on spreading the word about the danger of skin cancer and importance of protecting skin. I’ve only been to the beach once since my op and I was very nervous, sitting under an umbrella the whole time. “I wear factor  sunscreen every day now - evenit’s pouring with rain - and I always wear a hat outside. “A lot of my friends have stopped lying around on tanning beds. I have to say - take a look at the pictures. They would certainly stop me.”

title: curran an injury worry for dundee ahead of hibs clash on friday
story: Craig Curran is Dundee’s major fitness doubt for their Friday night clash with Hibs at Dens Park.The former Dundee United and Ross County striker played at Livingston last weekend but has been nursing a stomach problem since the draw with Kilmarnock a fortnight ago.He hardly trained last week and has been missing again over the past few days.“Craig is very sore, he didn’t train all last week because of a stomach thing,” said boss Jim McIntyre.“He’s going to require a few days to get over it.”If it’s a case of wait and see with Curran, Jim is confident both Andrew Nelson and Andreas Hadenius will make it.Nelson had to come off after netting the equaliser at Livi when he aggrevated ankle and calf problems as he celebrated his goal.And Swede Hadenius was replaced early in the second half at the weekend after picking up a knock.Both, though, have responded to treatment and are expected to be fit for Friday.With four goals since his arrival from Sunderland last month, -year-old Nelson is the man of the moment at Dens.While the manager stresses the young attacker remains a work in progress, he’s been delighted with his performances so far.“Nelson is a goalscorer and I thought his finish at the weekend was excellent,” Jim added.“It looked ashe was stretching but he’s managed to generate it into the corner.“As I’ve said before, he is raw. He still needs a lot of work, working with a partner and when to link and stuff but I’m delighted with his goals contribution so far.”

title: dundee boss mcintyre ready to cross swords with new hibs gaffer heckingbottom
story: Jim McIntyre and Paul Heckingbottom will cross swords for the first time in their managerial careers when Dundee and Hibs clash at Dens tonight.However, while Jim admits to knowing little of his opposite number, his knowledge of the team he’ll be putting out means he’s not expecting too many tactical surprises.Hibs appointed Heckingbottom as the successor to Neil Lennon last week and he kicked off his time in Scotland with an Easter Road win over Hamilton Accies.While, in time, the Dee boss knows his opposite number will put his own stamp on the Hibees, right now he’s not expecting too many drastic tactical changes from the way they lined up under Lennon.“I don’t know him but he got off to a good start and Hibs have good players. It’s going to be a tough game,” said Jim.“He’s got good options as well, you need to be able to handle that.“We know what players he’s got to work with and we know their strengths and weaknesses like we do most of the other squads in the league. It’s about making sure yours are better than theirs on the night, that’s how it is in football.“We are back at home in front of the cameras and want to put on a good performance.”Dundee go into the game boosted by last week’s vital win at Livingston that hauled them out of the bottom two in the top flight for the first time since late August.Again, though, the manager is stressing it’s where the team are at the end of the season that counts.“We could be back down there come Saturdaywe don’t keep it going.“Livingston is gone now and now it’s all about this one.”

title: family pays tribute to dundee guitarist kenny whose music took him all over the world
story: The family of a popular Dundee musician have led tributes to the talented guitarist following his death at the age of .Kenny Day died last weekend having spent the last years of his le living with dementia.A well-known figure on the Dundee music scene, Kenny, from Lochee, played in bands such as The Bad Pennies, Ringer and Sanjo during the s and s.His touring career took him across Scotland and the world where he performed in Germany and New York.Kenny’s son, Kenneth Day Jr, said: “It didn’t matter what it was – everything was a joke to my dad.“I remember his car broke down one night in Germany and he managed to fix the fan belt with women’s tights which were in the car.“A few months later he was still driving around with the tights connected to the fan belt.“He liked the women too. He had all the ladies around him. Even in the care home, he was a charmer.”His daughter, Jackie, , from Fintry, said: “I want people to know how talented he was – music was his le.“He first started out at about age four when he sang on stage with his sister Wilma but he first picked up a guitar at age  and I’m not surehe stole his older brother’s guitar.”Jackie said her father had a wide taste in music, although The Beatles were his favourite and his band Ringer would often cover songs by the Fab Four.Kenneth, , from Menzieshill, said he was inspired to take up guitar by his father.He said: “He would always ask me, ‘which Beatles song are we going to learn this week ’“I play in a band now and took it from my dad. People know my dad – after I put it on Facebook I’ve just had loads of comments with people saying that my dad was like a mentor to them.“Some musicians have been in touch to say my dad taught them how to play.”Kenny’s elder sister, Phyllis Duffin, , from Craigiebank, said his talents went beyond his musical knowledge, adding: “He had learnt six languages from French, Spanish, Urdu to Polish. He was very talented but had no common sense.“He loved going to Campbeltown in the west of Scotland to visit his cousins. I remember phoning through at one point and his cousin telling me he had been chasing their car in a Wombles suit!”Kenny, who was the youngest of four siblings, was diagnosed with dementia in his early s and entered a care home.Jackie said: “He would forget lyrics, it’s like he was fading away. It was a horrible thing to watch.“It was hard for him, he couldn’t drive anymore but he knew what was ahead. He developed a stammer and got frustrated.”Kenneth said: “Dad was a smart man so it was heartbreaking to see him getting ill.“The other week we were all sitting round him and he hadn’t spoken in over two years but then he began blethering and singing in German.“I told my sister that dad was talking and then he recognised Phyllis when she came in.“His music was playing in the hospital room and my sister turned down the stereo.“Dad said, ‘don’t do that again’ – it was braw!”

title: shoppers complain of dundee post office mess as refurbishment is postponed
story: A Broughty Ferry Post Office has had its refurbishment delayed despite complaints of it being littered with “mess”.The Gray Street branch was originally going to close from February  to March  to be given a makeover but residents have now been told the refurbishment has been postponed “indefinitely”.Christine Kenny, from Broughty Ferry, regularly uses the branch.She said: “The condition of the Post Office is a disgrace, with quite a bit of litter around.“There are bags of rubbish dumped in the front shop.”She added: “It was to be refurbished, but when I was in today the assistant mentioned it has been postponed.“The Post Office should have a say about its condition.“Even a brush, cloth or duster wouldn’t go amiss.”Ferry councillor Craig Duncan spoke of the store’s condition, saying: “The refurbishment has been deferred by the postmaster rather than the Post Office. In a way it’s disappointing but it helps in the short term because the Barnhill Post Office remains closed due to fire damage.”He added: “A lot of these matters are down to the postmaster rather than the Post Office to deal with.“I understand the purpose of the refurbishment is to bring these things up to spec and I welcome that and it will happen at some point. It’s a sizeable building and most of the floor space is not being used at the moment.”“We don’t have a timescale for the works to be done but I’ll find out more in the next two to three months.“As soon as I am aware, I will make that public.”In a statement, the Post Office thanked the Tele for bringing the state of the store to their attention and said the postmaster will be contacted regarding the concerns.Postal services at the Barnhill office on Nursery Road have been closed since a fire at the MS News shop on October .The fire caused almost £, worth of damage, closing the store “indefinitely”.The Gray Street shop was closed in January last year until July, so the store could be made more modern.After the last refurbishment, the store had four serving positions on a modern-screened counter, two open-plan positions and a serving point at the retail section.The opening hours also increased by  hours a week, to operate from am-.pm.

title: tom duthie deeiy sos then dundee boss jim mcintyre is the man to call
story: Rather understandably, no one has asked Jim McIntyrehe’s a fan of the hit BBC show DIY SOS.Perhaps we should, becausehe leads Dundee to safety this season he might just be able to lay claim to being the Scottish Premiership’s version of its presenter Nick Knowles.For those lucky enough to watch only football on the box, it’s the one where Knowles and a team of tradesmen step in to help families or groups with building projects they don’t have the knowhow or resources to complete on their own. To add to the drama, it’s done as a race against the clock.And McIntyre is gaining a growing reputation for doing the same with top-flight clubs here.Four-and-a-bit years ago he arrived at Ross County with the Highland outfit seemingly already doomed to relegation.By the end of that season he hadn’t just kept the Staggies up, he’d rebuilt them into a squad that would go on and win silverware in the shape of the  League Cup.After the Dark Blues’ weekend win at Livingston got them out of the bottom two for the first time since the end of August, thanks to goals from new handy men Andrew Nelson and Scott Wright, there are strong signs he can do the same at Dens Park.McIntyre’s reign as Dundee boss started in October when he received an SOS from owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms.After a miserable start to the campaign, the Americans’ dream of cementing their team as a force in the Premiership and, eventually, taking the club to a new stadium looked in danger of crumbling around them.Confirmation of just how dire the need for an emergency rebuild came in his first game in charge when the roof fell in during a - defeat at Livi. It showed how flimsy the foundations of the team were as they collapsed under the weight of the home team’s excellence at set-pieces.Almost exactly four months on and after that second visit to the Tony Macaroni Arena under the new boss, the structure looks much more sound.And it’s all thanks to the kind of speedy reconstruction he undertook at County and of which Knowles and his team would be proud. For the team that ran out against Livi at the weekend bore no resemblance to the one McIntyre had to work with when he first headed there.Not one of the players in the starting XI in October were on from the start this time and of the  who were involved on that first day,  have left the club.Only Kenny Miller, Cammy Kerr and Elliott Parish remain and, of those three, veteran Miller was the sole participant in the vital - victory.For McIntyre, to bring about almost a complete change in such a short space of time has been a gamble, one that will only be confirmed as paying offhis team are still in the Premiership come the end of the season.It’s one, though, that represents his best chance of success and it is very much a case of so far so good.While Dundee under him remain a work in progress, the signs of improvement have been there for all to see.Since the end of the winter break there have been two wins, two draws and just one defeat in five league outings.By some margin that’s been the best run of form in the top flight so far this term.If it continues there is every reason to believe that target of building a team good enough for this level by the end of the season will have been achieved.Andthat is the case, fans will be hoping given more time, the manager will be able to set about putting together something even more impressive for next season and beyond.

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Final page turned for Invernesss Christian bookshop
story: A CHRISTIAN bookshop in Inverness which has served the Highlands for nearly four decades will soon be closing.The CLCbook-shop in Castle Street provides literature from a Christian viewpoint to local churches and has been a resource centre for the wider community.CLC is a charity which started in Colchester in  and has been operating in Inverness for about  years.Prior to its move to Castle Street about eight years ago the shop was located in Church Street.Shop manager Pam Kerr said the closure decision follows a dropping off in customer footfall.ldquoItrsquos sad because as well as being a valuable resource centre for the Christian community it was a very popular place for people to come in for a coffee and to enjoy some fellowship, she said, adding that its resources will continue to be sold online.Miss Kerr, who is a member of the Inverness Christian Fellowship which meets at Merkinch Community Centre every Sunday, said that although the shop was closing an exact date would depend on how soon someone is found to take over the lease.ldquoCLC has been in Inverness for nearly  years and I have been the manager of the shop since it moved to Castle Street, she said.ldquoAs well as providing resources for local churches and the Christian community we supply to places like Wick, Thurso, Ullapool and Skye.ldquoBefore the shop opened here in Inverness CLC had a van which travelled from Aberdeen supplying local churches and the Christian community and attended local fairs and shows where it ran stalls.The specialist chain provides books and resources, including films, music and seasonal gts.The closure is just the latest in Castle Street where Tomlinsons Beer Shop closed in August last year after six years in business.It was closely followed by the closure of the CoolNess ice cream parlour on the site of the former Nessiersquos Arcade.Agents for the owners reported the business had been ldquobarely breaking even.Mike Smith, manager of Inverness Business Improvement District previously said the closure was ldquounfortunate but hoped a new tenant would be found soon for a business that was ldquowell fitted out.This week signs outside the parlour suggested the site is currently under offer.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: First phase of 32m refurbishment completed at Inverness school
story: THE first phase of a major refurbishment programme at an Inverness primary school has been completed.Two new classrooms have opened at Smithton Primary, much to the delight of principal teacher Lynne Macdonald who said the new facilities increased opportunities for its  children as well as staff.Pupils have also got a new a multiuse games area.ldquoItrsquos made a huge dference, she said.ldquoIt gives us a lot more space and just little things like having blackout blinds on sunny days and having all the children in seats at the same height really helps.The pound. million refurbishment project to address the schoolrsquos current and future capacity needs began last April.Once completed, it will see a total of five additional classrooms created along with two support needs rooms, a dedicated space for senior pupils and an extended gym hall.Local councillor Trish Robertson said it was excellent to see the project start to take shape.ldquoThe expansion was badly needed and having the extra space must be better for the children, she said. ldquoIrsquom really pleased itrsquos gone up so quickly.Iain MacDonald, special works manager for Morgan Sindall, which is carrying out the renovation work, said construction was currently on track for completion by September.ldquoThe most important thing for us has been not to interrupt the daily activity of the school, he said.ldquoBut another big thing is giving the kids a good experience of construction ndash therersquos a perception that construction is about the trades but therersquos so much more to get involved in.Miss Macdonald added: ldquoThe workers have been great. They always make sure they receive any deliveries before am which really helps and means the construction isnrsquot impacting the children. Thatrsquos the most important thing.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Funding blow to Highland food banks charity
story: North-based charity Blythswood Care has issued a public appeal for more donations after it lost an annual pound, recycling grant from Highland Council in the recent local authority budget.The charity which has one of the largest networks of food banks in the Highlands handles around  tonnes of clothing donations a year at its Evanton depot of which more than  per cent was reused or recycled.Previously the council financially supported the recycling work and some local authority properties already host textile banks for taking unwanted clothing deposits but this year withdrew support.The council had to plug an almost pound million financial hole in its budget amid shrinking government grants for core services, the moves was called a ldquobody blow by operations manager Ian Matheson who admitted the loss of the recycling grant is not a complete surprise.ldquoWe recognise that the Council has been faced with hard decisions. Wersquove enjoyed a mutually beneficial partnership with Highland Council for over  years and we really appreciate that, he said.ldquoTheir support has enabled us to develop our re-use and recycling activities, reducing waste, providing local employment and raising support for projects such as Blythswoodrsquos Highland Food Bank.ldquoDonations of clothing, bric-a-brac and quality furniture from the general public are going to be more important to us than ever as we aim to continue this aspect of our work despite the loss of this grant.The organisation processes more than , tonnes of donations a year at its Evanton depot, producing goods for its charity shops and selling on to processors in other parts of the country.Mr Matheson said ldquoWe have to constantly review all that we do and consider what efficiencies we can make. You can help us now by giving our shops your custom and donations.ldquoAll donations will be gratefully received so we can have continuity of employment ndash because this is about jobs too ndash as well as maintain service provision.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have had very positive discussions with Blythswood and these are ongoing about how we can possibly work together in the future.Blythswood welcomes donations of textiles, footwear, bric-a-brac, small electrical goods, books and good quality furniture.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Roads not safe for city cyclists says Inverness campaigner
story: A LOT needs to be done to bring roads in Inverness up to a standard that makes them safe and easy for road users to navigate, a leading cycling campaigner has said.Brian MacKenzie, convener of the Highland Cycle Campaign, said: ldquoI cycle a lot and there is no doubt the roads in the town are in very poor condition.ldquoThe trunk roads, too, need attention.Championing the cause for better and safer routes for cyclists he said drivers also need to be aware of cyclists and give greater consideration to them.ldquoDrivers often criticise cyclists when they see them weaving along certain routes but often they are doing that simply to avoid potholes and are taking evasive action, he said.ldquoAt the Raigmore Interchange, on the ramp joining the A south from the A, there is a pothole which has been there for some time. It is now gathering water and there is a warning sign for traffic alerting them to flooding.ldquoThere are also two more long potholes which are much more dangerous for cyclists and motorists just as you enter the interchange off the northbound ramp, coming from the Beechwood direction of the A.ldquoThe seal between the interchange and the ramp has gone andyou are cycling along there on a dark night you canrsquot see it, so your wheel can get caught up in it. These are like tram lines and they could throw you off a bike and cause serious injury.ldquoEvery vehicle coming from the A has to go across these potholes as they enter the interchange as well and they have been like that for a considerable time.ldquoI am wondering when the trunk roads people are going to carry out these repairs.While Highland Council is responsible for the upkeep of most roads in Inverness and the surrounding towns and villages, Bear Scotland is responsible for trunk roads.A spokesman for the organisation told the Courier last week that major defects, including deeppotholes which could pose a danger to road users, are repaired within  days, with safety inspections of all roads under its care inspected on a weekly basis.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Stonework at the Academy Street entrance to Invernesss Victorian Market is to be refurbished at a cost of pound,.The sum will be coveredby grants from the Academy Street Townscape Heritage Trust andInverness Common Good Fund .The decision to push ahead with the project will mean a delay to other planned mechanical and electrical works, alongwith the installation ofnew doors at the market.pound, remains allocated towards the upgrading of shopfronts at the market, including new lighting and flooring.Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: Sugars night set to be sweet for Highland Hospice
story: AN evening of fun, quality entertainment and good food has been promised by an Inverness man who is raising money for the Highland Hospice.Alastair Kennedy, communications director at Global Energy Group and chairman of Nigg Skills Academy, is calling on local businesses to try and help with his fundraising for this yearrsquos Strictly Inverness dancing competition.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom hoping that the business community will support this amazing cause as they have done in the past.Known to his friends as Sugar, Mr Kennedy will be hosting a dinner called Sugarrsquos Strictly Big Night at the Kingsmills Hotel in Inverness on April .The black tie tartan event will consist of live music from local band Torridon as well as an auction, quiz and a raffle, with all proceeds going to the hospice.Mr Kennedy is reaching out to the local business community to come along and support the event so he can raise as much money as possible.The director of Ross County Football Club is well known for his enjoyable hosting of hospitality at their home matches over the past  years, and thinks he has the the expertise and dry sense of humour to host another entertaining and enjoyable evening for all.As the oldest ever competitor in Strictly Inverness, Mr Kennedy was inspired to get involved in this yearrsquos event after sadly losing his mother to cancer in . She spent her final days in the hospice.ldquoTheir facilities and the care they provided for my mum was just so wonderful and considerate, he said.ldquoThey looked after her so well in her last days with us. I said at the time that I must, at some point in the future, do something to raise much-needed funds for the hospice, and with it being their th Strictly anniversary year, I just thought maybe now is the time.ldquoThere are lots of couples competing for the Strictly Inverness title and there is already great camaraderie being built up between us all.ldquoThis is not so much about winning, itrsquos more about raising money for this most worthy cause and everyone is working so hard not just in dance training, but in raising money by whatever means. I am hoping my business connections will assist me in being able to create a great night, but also raise as much money as possible for the hospice.Tables cost pound for  people and anyone interested should contact Mr Kennedy via Global Energy Group.Strictly Inverness also raises money for Inverness Ice Centre, which hosts the showdown from May .Sunday  Feb  : PM

title: shinnie double secures seventh straight away win for aberdeen
story: ABERDEEN secured a seventh straight away victory as skipper Graeme Shinnie fired a devastating double to dump St Johnstone - in Perth.Club captain Shinnie netted superb goals either side of the break to move the Dons to within two points of second placed Rangers who are in action tomorrow.Aberdeen made two changes to the side held - at home to Premiership bottom club St Mirren.last weekend.Dom Ball came in for Tommie Hoban who suffered a season ending cruciate ligament injury against the Buddies at the weekend.Hoban, who was on loan from Premier League Watford, will undergo surgery.Also coming into the starting line-up was Connor McLennan with Niall McGinn dropping to the bench.Ball went into the right back position normally occupied by Shaleum Logan who it has been confirmed will undergo surgery on an ankle injury and could be ruled out for the season.On loan Rotherham defender Ball impressed in the right-back role.Aberdeen grabbed the lead in the th minute when Ball stole the ball off Kennedy before sliding a pass to Graeme SHINNIE.Scotland international Shinnie cut past Sean Goss before unleashing a precision right footed shot past Cammy Bell from the edge of the penalty area.It was a quality finish from Shinnie, who is out of contract at the end of the season and has yet to make a decision on his future.Aberdeen have offered Shinnie a lucrative new contract but the Pittodrie club remain in limbo..Shinnie was again at the heart of the action in the st minute to recover a precarious situation for Aberdeen as on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe lost possession in the St Johnstone half when pushing forward.It created a hole at the back that Goss exploited with a superb cross field ball flighted in behind the fractured rear-guard to release Chris Kane in on goal.Just as he was about to shoot from  yards out Shinnie made up vital ground before pitching in with a tackle to dispossess him.In the th minute Aberdeen were denied when Gary Mackay-Steven met a McLennan cross to unleash a  footed right footed volley that keeper Bell blocked.Moments later Dons keeper Joe Lewis was called into action as he tipped a  yard header from Murray Davidson over the bar.In the th minute teenager Lewis Ferguson, who this week signed a two year contract extension until , fired a powerful  yard drive across the face of goal and just wide.Aberdeen should have increased their advantage in the th minute when Shinnie burst into the box to collect a pass from Stewart before crossing low to find McLennan in space.However the winger, back into the starting line up, blasted over from  yards.The woodwork denied Saints in the th minute when a drilled cross from Kennedy came off the outstretched boot of Mikey Devlin and cracked off the post.Captain SHINNIE netted his second goal to make the three points safe when he won the ball on the half-way line before powering up-field.Shinnie then unleashed a superb left footed  yard drive beyond keeper Bell.ABERDEEN: Lewis, Ball, Devlin, Considine, Lowe, Ferguson, Shinnie, Stewart, Mackay-Steven, McLennan, Cosgrove.Subs: McGinn , May , Gleeson .Subs not used: Cerny, Virtanen, Campbell, WilsonST JOHNSTONE: Bell, Tanser, Shaughnessy, Davidson, Kane, Wotherspoon, Kerr, Foster, Craig, Goss, Kennedy.Subs: Watt , Swanson , Hendry .Subs not used: Hurst, Alston,  Callachan, Keown.Referee: Euan title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAn environmental group lobbying for the reintroduction of a long-extinct big cat to the UK has its eye a potential release site in Kintyre.The Lynx UK Trust has identied the region as one of three locations # the others being Queen Elizabeth Forest Park in the Trossachs and Glen Feshie, next to the Cairngorms National Park # which the trust want to use as release sites for the Eurasian lynx, which was hunted to extinction around , years ago in the UK.The group quotes research which it claims shows Scotland#s forests could sustain around  of the cats, helping to control the deer population and leading to a regeneration of forest ecosystems.To back up the controversial plans, the group claims that no lynx attack humans has ever been recorded.The prospect of the creatures# re-introduction has not been welcomed by farmers, amid concerns that the cats could attack livestock.The trust, however, says sheep are an #exceptionally rare target# for lynx.Borders livestock farmer and NFU Scotland vice president Rob Livesey called The Lynx UK Trust#s latest announcement #brazen#, adding: #The process for securing permission for the trial release of lynx is long and complex and any application would be subject to considerable analysis and debate.#Farmers and crofters should be confident that NFU Scotland, as a member of the National Species Reintroduction Forum, will represent their best interests and ensure this application is thoroughly scrutinised.#A public drop in consultation on the plans is scheduled for Tuesday March  from pm to pm in Tarbert Village Hall.

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

A long ball to the right hand side was met by Ryan Caskie who cut the ball back to Stuart McLean. The youngster took a touch before slotting past the Pupils# goalkeeper to give Star a - lead.Star continued to press and doubled their lead when Coll McCallum robbed the Pupils# defender on the edge of the box before cutting the ball across goal. The unfortunate Pupils# defender could only ert the ball into the empty net, with McLean waiting on a tap in. The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. The equaliser arrived with  minutes remaining when good play from Pupils down the right by Soudan saw him get a low cross in which was met by the on-rushing run of Ryan Deans and he finished well to level the score at -.This set up a frantic finish and both sides could have nicked it towards the end. title: districts week 08
