That was rejected, with the council keen to see the land retained for employment.After being contacted by the Courier for a comment, a spokesperson for Starbucks said: ldquoUnfortunately, we donrsquot have anything to share at the moment.

title: east-lothian-mp-shares-his-views-on-eight-labour-mps-resigning
story: Martin Whitfield, who was elected as MP for East Lothian in , has spoken following eight fellow Labour MPs resigning from the party.Seven MPs ndash Luciana Berger, Ann Coffey, Mike Gapes, Chris Leslie, Gavin Shuker, Angela Smith and Chuka Umunna ndash announced their decision on Monday, which comes in protest at Labour leader Jeremy Corbyns leadership, as well as the handling of allegations of anti-Semitism in the Labour Party.They were joined on Wednesday by an eighth MP, Joan Ryan, as well as three Conservative MPs who resigned from their party.The  MPs will now sit in Parliament as the Independent Group.Commenting on the Labour resignations, Mr Whitfield said: ldquoThe MPs who have resigned are good colleagues and friends and I am very sad that they felt they had no other option but to leave the party.ldquoMy own position is that I was immensely proud to be elected as a Scottish Labour MP here in East Lothian and have never considered leaving."I am Labour through and through and will continue to fight my corner within the party.ldquoHowever, the departure of these seven colleagues highlights the importance of the party leadership urgently addressing issues like anti-Semitism and the behaviour of a minority of members, as well as listening to members and supporters on Brexit.ldquoHistory shows us that it is only when Labour is operating as a broad church, open, inclusive and tolerant of a range of opinions, that it can unite to deliver the change working people need.

title: musselburgh-man-given-interim-asbo
story: Jordan Buchan, , of Goose Green Avenue, has been banned from shouting, swearing, or using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or behaviour within his property or within Goose Green Avenue, or permitting or encouraging others to do the same.Mr Buchan is also banned from engaging in acts of physical violence or permitting or encouraging others to do the same in or near a property at Goose Green Avenue.The interim ASBO also bans Mr Buchan from generating any kind of excessive noise such as the repeated banging or slamming of doors and having more than two visitors to his property, except those there in the course of their employment.A council spokesperson said: ldquoEast Lothian Council will take the appropriate legal action against those who persistently behave in a way that causes alarm and distress to others."Anyone in East Lothian who is affected by anti-social behaviour can call the councilrsquos dedicated  hours a day helpline on  .

title: couples-quick-wedding-after-brides-dad-given-weeks-to-live
story: Bex Wood, neacutee Cunningham, was not even engaged when she found out that her dad, George Cunningham, had just weeks to live.Bex, along with boyfriend Ali Wood, quickly got engaged and got married just six days after the doctors broke the bad news to her dad.She told the Courier: ldquoThe wedding was brilliant.ldquoIt was quite bittersweet but from looking back at photographs, everybody commented on how happy everybody was.ldquoWe could have made it a sad day but we did not want that.ldquoIt was a still a celebration it was perfect, the weather was great ndash everything.ldquoThat was how it would have gonewe took a couple of years to plan it.George, , of Longniddry, had been suffering from stomach pains last year.Bex told the Courier: ldquoHe was diagnosed with lymphoma last June.ldquoThey said they were putting him on a curative plan and said to him he could be home and cured by Christmas.ldquoHe was getting treatment but then in October he started to get more treatment.ldquoThey did tests and just found out it was not working and he only had weeks to live.Ali and Bex had been together for five years and had spoken of getting married but had never really put any plans into motion.However, after the diagnosis, Ali went shopping for an engagement ring and proposed on the Sunday.The couple, who live in Prestonpans, tied the knot on the Thursday at Longniddry Parish Church before a reception at Archerfield House.Despite the short timeframe, Bex said the couple were not overly stressed by the occasion, with Alirsquos sister-in-law Lyndsay putting things together.Bex, , said: ldquoYou need a team of people to help. We hardly did any of it ourselves ndash Alirsquos sister-in-law pretty much did all of it.ldquoShe was the events planner at Archerfield and she did pretty much all of it.ldquoFamily did bits and pieces but Lyndsay did most of it so we cannot take any of the credit.The happy couple were married on November , with George walking his daughter down the aisle in front of  guests.Medical sales rep Bex said: ldquoHe was absolutely fine on the day.ldquoHe was a bit tired and went for a lie down but he walked me down the aisle no bother.ldquoHe did his speech and the first dance together and then he just sat and everybody chatted to him.George sadly passed away on November , with the funeral taking place in the same church.Bex and Ali, who works as a field sales manager, decided to hold off on a honeymoon, with the couple jetting off to Dubai and the Males next month.Bex added: ldquoWe wanted to spend as much time with him as possible.ldquoWe had no idea in terms of timeframes so we spent everyday with him.An online fundraising page has also been set up to raise money for Bloodwisego to justgiving fundraising alastair-wood

title: substation-plan-at-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-approved
story: The site, which is owned by East Lothian Council and had been earmarked as having the potential to bring more than , jobs to the community, has been at the centre of a battle between the community, the council and windfarm company Inch Cape.Ministers called in the planning application from Inch Cape,which wants to bring energy from a planned offshore windfarm onshore at the site, before East Lothian Council had made any ruling on it.The call-in was controversially made while First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was visitingChina, where she met representatives of the Chinese state-owned Red Rock company, which owns Inch Cape.Issuing their decision, Scottish Ministers said they agreed with the Scottish Government reporterrsquos findings that the substation was of ldquonational importance.East Lothian Council and local communities had argued it would ldquosterilise the site for future economic development.However, the reporter noted that the substation would take up less than  per cent of the former power station site.

title: new-cemetery-at-dunbar-gets-the-go-ahead
story: A total of , lairs,  ashes-only lairs and an area of woodland burial space will be created at Newtonlees, on the eastern edge of the town.The announcement brings to an end fears that the town would be left without any burial space.Deer Park Cemetery, opposite the newly-approved burial ground, is nearly at capacity.Now, the new cemetery is expected to serve the people of Dunbar and surrounding area for at least  years.The announcement was welcomed by ward councillor Norman Hampshire, who was keen to see the new cemetery opened quickly.He said: ldquoIt will take time for people to do the work they have to do to get the facility into a place that can be used.ldquoI know Stuart Pryde [council principal amenities officer] and his team have been ready and waiting for this to happen.Deer Park Cemetery, which has , lairs, opened in  and is expected, according to the council, to reach capacity by the summer of next year.Plans to extend the cemetery fell through, with the council then forced to look for land for a new cemetery.Currently, the new site is being used as agricultural land but work is expected to begin in the near future on transforming the .-hectare site off the A.According to the planning officerrsquos report: ldquoThe supporting information submitted with the application states that the burial site is required to meet both the immediate needs of Dunbar town but also to serve the needs of the wider cluster of communities for the next - years in accordance with the councilrsquos approved Burial Ground Strategy.ldquoThe general layout of the Newtonlees Cemetery reflects best practice in terms of modern burial ground provision.ldquoThe layout affords a degree of choice from traditional coffin interment through interment of cremated remains and an allocation of space for natural burial within a meadow woodland area which will, as it develops, also provide an enhanced setting for the facility.The cemetery is part of larger plans for the site, which were first discussed by councillors in .At that time, plans for more than  houses on land at Newtonlees Farm were approved, despite the area of land being outwith the sites identied at that stage by the councilrsquos Local Development Plan and recommended for refusal by the local authorityrsquos planning officers.At that time, the vote was tied at -, with Mr Hampshire given the casting vote.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said details were still to be finalised before a date could be confirmed for the cemetery opening.She added: ldquoHaving secured approval and agreement to purchase the ground, we can now ensure that local burial space supply will continue for the area without risk of a break in service.

title: tims-tales-the-kings-chair
story: IT HAS been a time of lsquoborrowed daysrsquo recently. Such days are ones which have been borrowed from another month, and I think given the temperature and weather we have had recently the days have been borrowed from May.In , May will have borrowed Februaryrsquos days, so we can expect some unseasonal weather in that month as well, but in a dferent way.Sunday was a borrowed day for sure it was so mild and the later part sunny with a feeling of spring in the air. It was a perfect day for a discovery.We set off to find a place Irsquod only recently heard about. A friend had asked me what I knew about the lsquoKingrsquos Chairrsquo by Gullane. I had to admit that Irsquod never heard of it. He told me one of the holes at the golf course there has this name, but it seems it is named after a location nearby.This set me investigating. Sure enough, I found it marked on the map and searched for an image, which I found on a website called Ancient Stones: a large boulder, shaped like a throne, guarded by two other stones either side. It intrigued me and so our quest began.The starting point of our adventure was Gullane Beach car park. I knew roughly where to look but purposefully hadnrsquot brought the map so that we had a challenge to find the lsquochairrsquo. We knew what it looked like and that we needed to walk along the upper path, not the one that heads for the beach.We went the wrong way at first and got stuck in a mass of sea buckthorn, but on reflection that just added to the sense of adventure and achievement. We soon found our way and then suddenly there it was, up on Gullane Hill. The kids ran excitedly towards the stones, shouting: ldquoFound it, found it.I felt quite exhilarated at the discovery, and to be honest impressed by the sight of the Kingrsquos Chair. I can see how it got its name, as it looks something like a majestic reclining armchair. The two boulders on either side of it look like sentries keeping watch.The kids sat on it, of course, and I had to wait my turn after my we, who reckoned it could just as easily be a lsquoQueenrsquos Chairrsquo.When I finally got a chance to seat my majestic posterior on the chair, I realised the view was majestic as well, with Gullane Beach very visible in the near distance.I reflected on the fact we had recently visited Edinburgh Castle and seen the Stone of Destiny or Stone of Scone, along with the crown jewels. This rather uninspiring stone in Edinburgh Castle may be the coronation stone used for  years in England, but it is not, I am sure, the coronation stone used by ancient kings of Scotland, despite official claims that it is.I think itrsquos pretty clear that Edward I never got his hands on the real Stone of Destiny and I am convinced it has remained in Scotland, hidden somewhere, ever since. It occurred to me that this stone actually better fitted the early description of the original coronation stone at Scone than the one in Edinburgh Castle.ldquoImaginethis is the real Stone of Destiny and has been here all the time, I said fancully out loud. I know it isnrsquot, of course, but I have to saythis Kingrsquos Chair was on display at Edinburgh Castle it would certainly look more authentic.But sadly there seems to be no recorded tradition connected to this Kingrsquos Chair. I could find no story, or reference to the origin of its name. Perhaps some local people have some information on this There is an entry from the s that records the name, citing locals as the source, so there is some historic veracity in its title. But no suggestion is offered for the origin of the name, or any tradition associated with the stone. Its geology I could not say but it doesnrsquot seem to be a glacial erratic.And so we are left to wonder. We discussed how the stone got here and how it got its name. Maybe some children played here many generations ago and gave the boulder its title. Perhaps a Viking king who landed on Gullane Beach sat himself down on this natural throne to survey his warriors at their bloody work.Whatever the origin, the name, the location and the nature of the stone make this a worthwhile and fun discovery, even without a firm legend attached to it.And as I sat on the chair I watched smoke billowing from the coastline a little further to the west, close to the edge of Aberlady nature reserve. What caused the fire I didnrsquot know, but even from a distance it seemed destructive.It was a prophetic sight to witness from the Kingrsquos Chair. It looked like a burning coastline from a Viking raid. Thankfully the distant screech of fire engines told us help was on the way. The children wanted to go see the fire, but we kept our distance from the flames and let the firefighters do their job.So the trip to the Kingrsquos Chair had been an adventure in more ways than one. On our way back, the children advanced dferent theories about the origin of the name. It was universally agreed that a story must be made, but no agreement on the actual tale.ldquoPerhaps, I said, ldquowe should leave it to the imagination of those who search for and discover it, so they can sit and feel the power of the place and get ideas.My imagination was certainly ablaze. I saw the leader of the ancient Gododdin tribe, King Loth, sitting on the stone, looking out to the Firth as he watched his terried daughter in a small coracle being taken out to the open sea, his brutal punishment for her defiance of his authority.The story would fit as her journey began at Aberlady Bay, and so her small craft would have been seen from the Kingrsquos Chair as it passed by, being pulled out to sea by one of the kingrsquos boats.Itrsquos all a fancy of my imagination, of course, but thatrsquos my story. Go find the Kingrsquos Chair for yourself and see what your imagination comes up with!

title: double-cash-boost-for-our-community-kitchen-project-in-haddington
story: Our Community Kitchen has been awarded more than pound,, which it will use over the next year.The bulk of the money has come from Big Lottery Scotland, with pound, awarded to see the group expand to three days a week from next month.Already, the project meets on a Tuesday at Haddington Bowling Club.In the coming weeks, it will also meet on a Wednesday and Thursday, hosting dozens of people at each session and serving a hearty three-course meal for a donation of pound.Elaine Gale, spokeswoman for the project, felt Our Community Kitchen was well on the road to being a success.She said: ldquoIt is so exciting for the area and just to see where we go next. There is hard work in the next six months as we build these two new days up.ldquoWhat I really love, what comes across very clear to everybody, is that there are no barriers at all.ldquoIt is people coming together, having something to eat, and natural things happen when people come together to eat. That, for me, is really special.ldquoThere is nobody specic invited ndash no age limits or ability ndash it is just people.ldquoIt is amazing people coming together, having some food and everybody is laughing their head off and having a blast.A further pound, was awarded by the Walk With Scott Foundation.Scott Glynn, who founded the charity, visited Our Community Kitchen last month and was impressed with what was on offer.A post on their social media said: ldquoIt was such a joy to see a project in action, people from all walks of le getting together to have lunch and a blether.ldquoThe smiles as they walked in and the contentment of a full belly after they had been served by wonderful volunteers was a joy to see.ldquoNothing was a trouble, and everything was done with a smile and a kind word.ldquoIt was decided to help this project with funding and we are proud to have offered them pound,, with the provision of having a couple of themed days: a Burns lunch, a Wimbledon day, a bowling day and, of course, their Christmas dinner ideas were suggested.For more information on the group, which meets at .pm at the bowling club on Wemyss Place, email elainegale@gmail

title: east-lothian-the-backdrop-for-budding-directors-movie-at-glasgow-film-festival
story: Connect was written and directed by Marilyn Edmond and premiered at the Glasgow Film Festival on Saturday.The film, which stars Kevin Guthrie, of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and Dunkirk, also features a number of East Lothian residents.Marilyn, who is originally from Prestonpans, was looking forward to the moviersquos first screening.She said: ldquoIt is really cool, amazing actually.ldquoIrsquom really excited about it and really happy the world premiere is in Scotland.Marilyn, who now lives in Glasgow, has been involved in film and television for nearly  years.She has worked as an assistant director on programmes ranging from Waterloo Road and Lovesick to Sunshine on Leith.However, Connect is her first time as writer and director, with the film also getting a second showingduring the -day festival. Both screenings are sold out.Marilyn revealed it was a tragedy that had moved her to create her first feature- film.She said: ldquoWhen I was working on one of the previous jobs, there was a guy that was an extra and he ended up committing suicide.ldquoIt just totally threw me.ldquoHe had posted on Facebook about how his le was brilliant and he was so happy and four months later he committed suicide.ldquoI was just gobsmacked with it.ldquoHe was only  and that really sticks with me.ldquoI feel his le had only just really started and I was really saddened by the news.ldquoAccompanied by all the stories in the media, it is quite a big subject.Writing on Connect began in November , with filming getting under way in May last year.That was wrapped up by November, with the film now finished and ready to be seen by the public.Thirty-seven-year-old Marilyn, who lived in North Berwick at the time of the filming, said: ldquoConnect is about a young man who is struggling and he is feeling suicidal.ldquoHe gets saved by a stranger and then is encouraged to live his le and reconnect with his family and friends ndash all the while he is battling his dark secret.Steampunk Coffee and Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware, both North Berwick, are among county locations used in the film, with Gullane Day Centre and Dunbar also featuring.There are also a handful of familiar faces as well, with Lynne Turnbull and Kenny Ainslie, who has carried boxer Josh Taylorrsquos Commonwealth super lightweight title to the ring, among those starring in the film.

title: prime-minister-rules-out-meaningful-vote-on-brexit-in-commons-this-week
story: Mrs May also said that Cabinet collective responsibility had not broken down after pro-EU ministers signalled they could support backbench moves to delay withdrawal in order to prevent a no-deal exit from the bloc.The PM said that because ldquopositive talks were ongoing with the EU, a meaningful vote would not be held this week.Speaking on her way to an EU-League of Arab States summit in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt, the Prime Minister said: ldquoI was in Brussels last week. Ministers were in Brussels last week. My team will be back in Brussels again this coming week. They will be ing to Brussels on Tuesday.ldquoAs a result of that we wonrsquot bring a meaningful vote to Parliament this week. But we will ensure that that happens by March .ldquoBut it is still within our grasp to leave the European Union with a deal on March .Asked how the Government would treat non-binding motions expected this week which call for the ruling out of a no-deal exit, and which demand an extension of Article , Mrs May said: ldquoWe donrsquot know what amendments are going to be tabled.ldquoWe donrsquot know what amendments are going to be selected.ldquoYou havenrsquot even seen what motion the Government is going to put down ndash as I say, it wonrsquot be the meaningful vote.ldquoI will be making a statement to Parliament on Tuesday. And then, obviously, wersquoll be having the debate the next day.The PM said the Government was still in talks with the EU about the Northern Ireland backstop.Mrs May said: ldquoWe are still in that negotiation. We are still talking to the EU about ious ways in which we can find a resolution to the issue that Parliament raised.The PM insisted collective Cabinet responsibility had not broken down after the intervention by Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke indicating that they could back parliamentary moves to stop a no deal.The PM said: ldquoNo, collective responsibility has not broken down.ldquoWhat we have seen around the Cabinet table, in the party, and in the country at large is strong views on the issue of Europe.ldquoThat is not a surprise to anybody.ldquoWe have around the Cabinet table a collective, not just responsibility, but desire, to actually ensure that we leave the European Union with a deal. Thatrsquos what wersquore working for and thatrsquos what Irsquom working for.Askedthe three ministers should remain in Government, Mrs May said: ldquoWhat we see around the Cabinet table is strong views held on the issue of Europe.Mrs May said that extending Article  would not deal with the issues.The PM said: ldquoNow, often people talk about the extension of Article  asthat will actually solve the issue. Of course it wonrsquot. It defers the point of decision. There comes a point where we need to make that decision.ldquoExtension of Article  doesnrsquot solve the problem.ldquoThere will always come a point where we have to decide whether we accept the deal thatrsquos been negotiated or not.ldquoAnd that will be a decision for every member of Parliament across the House.ldquoEvery member of the Commons will have to face that decision when that point comes.ldquoThe Government will be bringing back, working with the EU, and will want to put a deal to the House of Commons in a meaningful vote.Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer called Mrs Mayrsquos decision over the timing of the meaningful vote ldquoan admission of failure.He said: ldquoThis decision to further delay the meaningful vote is the height of irresponsibility and an admission of failure.ldquoTheresa May is recklessly running down the clock in a desperate attempt to force MPs to choose between her deal and no deal.ldquoParliament cannot stand by and allow this to happen.

title: temperatures-soar-to-historic-february-highs-in-wales
story: Less than  hours after Cardfrsquos Principality Stadium was the venue for an historic th consecutive test win for the hosts, people visiting hilly Gogerddan in Cardiganshire basked in highs of .Cndash making it the warmest Welsh day in February since .While the previous record of .C set in the rural south Wales village of Velindre took  years to be broken, forecasters said the new high may be surpassed again before the month is out.*** BREAKING NEWS *** #Wales has provisionally seen its highest ever February temperature at Gogerddan!! The previous record was . degC at Velindre on rd  pic zLmXllwTmdash Met OfficeFebruary , Becky Mitchell, forecaster with the Met Office, said: ldquoSouth-easterly winds today are likely to have contributed to the temperature, as well as the natural geography of the area.ldquoBut it could possibly get even warmer still. Wersquore looking at similar temperatures over the next few days.The temperature might have been affected by a phenomenon known as the Foehn Effect, a dry and warm down-slope wind that occurs to the lee of hills or mountains.Temperatures across Wales reached C in many places on Sunday, though it is unlikely to break the UK record for February ndash when the mercury soared to .C in Greenwich in .Should the temperatures rise to Cbefore Friday, it will be the earliest in the calendar year that such a milestone has been reached anywhere in the UK.

title: two-day-street-rave-taking-place-under-glasgow-motorway-this-summer
story: Platform  willto the city again for the two-day party under the bridge of West Street.After the success of last year, Platform  organisers have launched a second date, transforming into the cityrsquos only open-air techno street festival.Those behind the event will be confirming the full day-by-day lineup on Thursday, February . Tickets will go on sale the same day at am.:-hour car park rave under Glasgow rail bridges given go-aheadThe rave will happen on August  and .We reported back in June how the car park rave had been given the go-ahead to take place last summer by the council as organisers aimed to make it ldquoone of the best open-air street raves in Europe.The council heard at the time that the event was a positive way to bring young people in touch with mental health issues and that it had raised thousands for charity SAMH.Read more of todays top Glasgow stories

title: Iain Macwhirter  Get over it - cis women are just on the wrong side of history
story: This, apparently, is to educate heteronormative women about their ldquoprivilege ndash the fact that they can use the toilets, sorry ldquowashrooms, of their choice and access healthcare. Irsquom not sure who exactly has been preventing transgender women using public conveniences. So far as I know, you donrsquot have to show a birth certicate, or undergo a medical exam to have a pee. But what do I know as a pale, stale male.What I do know is that ldquocis-gender is an ugly neologism which many women find offensive. They are content with their present sexual terminology. ldquoCis is in the same linguistic ballpark as ldquoTERF ndash trans exclusionary radical feminist, which is a term of abuse used against women who believe persons with penises are, er, male. I should be careful here because a number of TERFS have been banned from social media for saying that a person with a penis is a man. So I wonrsquot say that.Instead, letrsquos just take it as read that in future we are going to have to accept that the concept of sexual dferentiation with which we have been living for thousands of years is finally being exposed as a malign transphobic hood. At any rate, the Scottish Government appears determined to press ahead with reform of the Gender Recognition Act, which will allow trans people to assign themselves legally and biologically female. Hitherto, trans people have had to undergo medical examination and get a diagnosis of ldquogender dysphoria. No more. From now on, anyone can change their birth certicate to whatever they wish.Earlier this month, Holyroodrsquos culture committee warned that ending binary ldquoMale or Female questions in the Scottish census will render much of the results meaningless and, willy nilly, import an unscientic definition of sex into the law. But the Scottish Government is not listening. Nicola Sturgeon told a UN equalities conference last week that the concerns of feminists about the GRA are ldquomisplaced.Women ndash sorry, ldquomenstruators ndash who say that self-ID erases their sexual identity will be told: just get over it. They can complain that ldquosex is a protected characteristic under the  Equalities Act, and that women therefore have a right to their own unique spaces. But now that men can actually become women under the law, this right will be impossible to articulate. Trans women with male anatomy will be entitled to enter womenrsquos changing rooms, girl guide troops or womenrsquos prisons. Women who complain will be guilty of transphobia, and are likely to be visited by the police recording a ldquohate incident.Now, I have nothing against adults changing their gender, or identying as women, queer, non-binary, intersex or whatever. It seems to be reinforcing outmoded concepts of gender to suggest that, because someone wants to wear dresses, play with dolls and put on makeup, they must have a lady brain in a male body. I thought we had left pink-for-girls gender stereotyping behind. But never mind. No-one wishes trans people any ill ndash certainly not me. But now that we are abandoning the very biological definition of sex, there are some anomalies that need to be addressed.Last week, a British transgender man, who had IVF by sperm donation and gave birth, won a court battle to prevent his child having ldquomother on its birth certicate. It will be the first child in history to have no mother. The The AIRE Centre, a human rights charity, contested this on the grounds that it would make le dficult for the child in future, when they apply for visas or anything which enquires about family background. The Government said simply that this isnrsquot a problem. From now on, fathers can give birth ndash end of.But Irsquom not sure this is the end of the matter. Children have not been included in the gender recognition debate thus far, even though they have rights too. It could be psychologically disturbing for a child to find, one day, that its mother has decided to become its dad. That song ldquoSometimes I feel like a motherless child takes on a whole new meaning.Of course, the trans parent will still be present, but is it OK to expect a child to suddenly start calling her natural mother her father  I would have thought that a child has a continuing right to a legal motherthey were born with one. If misgendering a trans person is unacceptable, surely demothering a child should be too. This is going to be confusing to say the least.Then there is the question of sport. The controversy over athlete Caster Semenya, a woman with high testosterone, raises the question of how to regard trans womenrsquos participation in women-only sport. Athletes who have testes, and therefore posses greater body mass, muscle strength and bone density, have an unfair advantage over old-fashioned women who have genetically female bodies.Next week, the International Association of Athletics Federations will argue in a hearing in Switzerland that people like Semenya should take testosterone-suppressing drugs before competing. Not only would this drive a coach and horses through the anti-doping protocols, it surely poses problem for transgender athletes who, of course, also take drugs like testosterone to help them transition to their ldquocorrect male sex. I hope the sporting authorities can get their heads around that because I canrsquot.Yet this is a very live issue in many sports. In the US, the ban on trans women taking part in power-lting events is being lted to prevent accusations of discrimination. You might have thought that having beefy, male-bodied women participating in these contests is discriminating against women athletes. Though, of course, only transphobes would say that, so we wonrsquot go there.The logical solution to this conundrum is to end sexual segregation in sport. Andwomen who are born biologically female never win any medals, tough. Strangely, there doesnrsquot seem to be the same issue about female-bodied trans men participating in male-only sport . Irsquom sure that has nothing whatever to do with the fact that they wonrsquot win anything.So welcome to the brave new world of post-sexual dferentiation, where men become women and fathers have children. It is one of the most radical and abrupt cultural changes in human history.Women have had a pretty bad deal in previous centuries, when they were regarded often as chattels without rights. In some Muslim societies theyrsquore still second-class citizens. Now, as women are finally emerging from the shadow of patriarchy, they are being told, by men, that they no longer have exclusive rights to their sexual identity.Itrsquos a weird turn of events. It seems women are just on the wrong side of history. But somehow, I donrsquot think theyrsquoll go quietly.

title: Glasgow  Gateway to Scotland  The best Charles Rennie Mackintosh within 90 minutes
story: The striking beauty and modernity of the work was not fully appreciated in his letime, though the vision of its ambitious creator is now recognised and celebrated around the world. Brad Pitt, Barbra Streisand and Madonna are among Mackintoshrsquos fans, and his pioneering designs continue to influence popular culture, not least in film and television, where sci-fi classics such as Bladerunner, Inception, Doctor Who and Star Wars ndash Darth Vader sits on a Mackintosh-inspired chair in the Empire Strikes Back ndash paid tribute to his geometric style.Nothing, however, compares to seeing and experiencing Mackintoshs work in person, and Glasgow is the best place in world to do so. Sadly, his masterpiece, Glasgow School of Art, was devastated in a second fire last year, with the schoolrsquos management pledging to rebuild, though this will clearly take many years.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best film locationsThere have been more positive developments where, of course, not least the opening of Mackintosh at The Willow, the stunning restoration of the original Willow Tearooms building on Sauchiehall Street. In Dundee, meanwhile, the new VA Museum ndash a world-class celebration of Scottish and international design - has Mackintosh at its beating heart.ldquoToshie as he was known to his friends, remains an indelible presence in the west of Scotland, though sometimes even Glaswegians become complacent about their cityrsquos most creative son. But thanks to Mackintoshs extraordinary creativity across the mediums therersquos always something new and interesting to see, whether yoursquore being introduced to the work for the first time or are a lelong admirer. With this in mind, wersquove put together a list of the best places to experience Mackintosh this year, all within  minutes of Glasgow.Queens Cross ChurchStill something of an under-appreciated gem, the only church designed by Mackintosh showcases his early promise. The unfussy, gothic-inspired building sits inconspicuously at a busy urban intersection on the edge of Maryhill, between the city centre and Glasgowrsquos west end, and you might easily walk past. Those who go inside are in for a treat, however, as the fully-restored interior highlights not only Mackintoshs love for nature but his appreciation of all things Japanese - not to mention is sense of humour.A favourite place of the late Princess Margaret, the church is now the home of the Charles Rennie Mackintosh Society, and offers year-round workshops, seminars, exhibitions, walks and talks. Itrsquos also one of Glasgowrsquos most beautul, intimate and under-rated music venues and hosts a wide array of concerts and events throughout the year. Garscube Road, Glasgow. Entry: pound. Children free. MackintoshchurchScotland Street SchoolOne of the biggest and best-loved of all Mackintoshrsquos buildings, the school ndash designed between  and  ndash provides a double whammy in terms of visitor experience. As well as exploring the amazing architecture, you get the chance to explroe the history of Scottish education in the fantastic hands-on displays, exhibitions and live performances that are dotted around this eminently family-friendly museum. Scotland Street, Glasgow. Free entry. Glasgowle.org museumsGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best whisky and BurnsKelvingrove Museum and Art GalleryArgyle Street, Glasgow. Glasgowle.org museumsHouse for an Art LoverDesigned as an entry to a prestigious German architecture competition, House for an Art Lover was conceived by Mackintosh in , but after being disqualied on a technicality, it was never built. Not in the architectrsquos letime, anyhow. The project was ambitiously resurrected in the s and the house finally opened in Glasgowrsquos south side,  years after its original conception, as country house, exhibition space, venue, cafeacute, restaurant and artistsrsquo studios, all set in beautul grounds. Dumbreck Road, Glasgow. Entry: pound pound.. Children under  go free. HouseforanartloverMackintosh at The WillowRe-opened last year in the citys Sauchiehall Street after an ambitious and meticulous poundm restoration, Mackintosh collaborator Kate Cranstonrsquos most iconic tea rooms provide a glorious insight into the pairrsquos creative partnership. Conceived as a complete work of art - a Gesamtkunstwerk - Mackintosh, alongside his we Margaret, designed every element of the building, inside and out, including furniture, wall decorations and accessories. But this is not a museum so much as a lively place to meet, eat, socialise and hold events. The afternoon tea is a delight.A new on-site visitor centre, staffed by volunteers, provides a wealth of information about the Mackintosh Cranston Macdonald legacy in Glasgow.- Sauchiehall Street. MackintoshatthewillowGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best film locationsThe LighthouseMackintoshrsquos first public commission was originally designed in  for The Herald, but since  it has housed event spaces, a cafe, Glasgowrsquos Centre for Architecture and Design, and a permanent exhibition and learning centre dedicated to its architect. The rooftop viewing area also provides some of the most spectacular views in the city.The Lighthouse, Mitchell Lane, Glasgow. Entry free.The Mackintosh HouseArguably nowhere better showcases Mackintoshrsquos genius as an interior designer than this wonderful recreation of the house he shared in the West End of the city, right next to the University of Glasgow, with Margaret.Featuring a meticulous reassembly of the principal apartments of their now demolished home in nearby Southpark Avenue, the apartments are filled with their original furniture and highlight the strikingly modern decorative vision shared by this remarkably modern couple.The Mackintosh House at the Hunterian, University of Glasgow. Entry: pound pound. Under s go free.VA DundeeBuilt on the banks of the Firth of Tay in Dundee, renowned Japanese architect Kengo Kuma ndash himself an acolyte of Mackintosh - has created a dramatic, beautul and entirely al base for Scotlandrsquos first dedicated design museum, with Mackintosh at the centre.Fully restored after half a century in storage, the magnicent Oak Room ndash the centrepiece of Miss Cranstonrsquos Ingram Street Tea Rooms in Glasgow ndash has been installed as the permanent centrepiece of the Scottish Design Gallery, on loan from Glasgow Museums.Riverside Esplanade, Dundee. Vam.ac.ukGlasgow, Gateway to Scotland: The best whisky and BurnsHill House, HelensburghThis ldquohome for the future in Helensburgh, an hour north west of Glasgow, is a particular favourite with many Toshie fans. Built for publisher Walter Blackie in , it is his domestic masterpiece and features many of the most recognisable designs and schemes, including the rose mot stencils.Problems with the exterior harling have always plagued the building, leading to water damage, and owners the National Trust for Scotland are currently building a ldquobox" around the house to protect it until a long-term solution can be found.Hill House is closed while the box is constructed, but will re-open to visitors in late spring.Upper Colquhoun St, Helensburgh. Entry pound. pound.. nts.org.ukMackintosh Club, HelensburghAnother Helensburgh gem is the Mackintosh Club, designed in  and now a hub for art, architecture and music.Sinclair Street, Helensburgh, G SU. Entry: pound. Mackintosh.clubDaily Record BuildingDesigned in  and tucked away from the bustle in a city centre lane, Mackintoshrsquos commission for the Daily Record now houses hip bar, cafe and music venue Stereo, and is a must-see stop on any city centre walking tour. Look upwards and you will see the striking use of colour on the faccedilade, which skilfully combines sculpted sandstone and white glazed bricks to maximise light. Listen carefully and you can almost hear the clack of the typewriters.Renfield Lane, Glasgow.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland a partnership between People Make Glasgow and Glasgow Airport, in association with The Herald, aims to attract more US visitors and capitalise on a recent growth in overseas tourists by highlighting the cityrsquos position as both a must-see destination in itself, and the ideal base for accessing Scotlandrsquos landscapes, history and culture.Delta flies direct to Glasgow from JFK www.delta.United flies direct from Newark www.united.

title: Rosemary Goring  Now is the time for the Catholic Church   s own Reformation
story: For this book Martel has conducted more than , interviews in the Vatican City in Rome, and across the world. He has spoken to priests, cardinals, bishops, monsignors, papal ambassadors, seminarians and the Swiss Guard. His conclusion, which will shock some and come as no surprise to others, is that about  per cent of the clergy in the Vatican state are gay. In other words, the HQ of a church that will not bless same-sex relationships, and forbids its clergy to have sex lives, is riddled with hyprocisy at its very core.Of these  per cent, Martel writes, some are celibate or in denial, others are living with their partners, or resort to prostitutes. A rule of thumb is that the more vehemently a cleric condemns homosexuality, the more likely he is to be in the closet himself. Hence the behaviour of the Colombian cardinal, Alfonso Lopez Trujillo. He was in the vanguard of the churchrsquos mission to prevent gay marriage. As the dire consequences of the Aids epidemic became clear, contrary to commonsense and compassion, he refused to encourage the use of condoms. Here was someone eager to be seen to uphold traditional values. Yet Martel claims that Trujillo, who died in , used male prostitutes.There are examples closer to home, among them the late Cardinal Keith OrsquoBrien, who pursued a similarly denunciatory anti-gay agenda, despite his own homosexuality and predatory behaviour. In fact, it doesnrsquot matter where you look. Throughout the Catholic churchrsquos parishes, globally and locally, there has been the mother of all cover-ups, not just in the buttoned-up past, but right now, here, today.You could say the church has been built on lies: countless men forced to hide who they really are, or to seek refuge in an all-male environment where they could find illicit love behind closed doors. Those clergy who were straight must have found themselves in a bewildering labyrinth of duplicity. That such depths of deceit have been allowed to thrive says all you need to know about the controlling power of those at the heart of the church.Martel believes that Pope Francis has earned enemies by adopting a very untypical approach. ldquoWho am I to judge  he replied, when askedhe condemned homosexuals, thereby loosening the ground beneath the feet of those in the Holy See who donrsquot want their secrets aired, or their way of le altered.The revelation of such widespread double standards is an echo of the medieval churchrsquos calamitous abuse of power and wealth. Out of it has sprung a culture where bullying, intimidation and blackmail have flourished. Andthat has been going on in this sphere, you can be sure it will have spilled over into every other part of the churchrsquos affairs.In the wake of the revelation of child abuse on a grand scale in the church, you begin to see why hiding the truth was the default position. This is not to make a link between homosexuality and child abuse but to see why the ecclesiastical authorities were so quick, and adept, at making the problem disappear. In avoiding scandal, they were intent on protecting their own rather than those who had been so grievously harmed.With evidence of institutionalised deception of the extent Martel claims, the church brings shame on itself: not for the numbers of priests who are gay, but for the willingness to lie about it, and to break vows, and the spirit of vocation, to an extent that will appall devout parishioners.Now is the time for the Catholic Churchrsquos own Reformation. No-one can any longer doubt that the le expected of a Catholic priest is unhealthy. And since there is no biblical injunction on him to be celibate, why can this not be changed  Already the church is embracing married Anglican vicars in flight from the ordination of women. Why not allow Catholic clergy the same right to open relationships, whether they be gay or straight Until the double-speak on which the modern church stands is addressed, there is no hope of winning back the faithful who have lost all trust and respect in this once revered institution. Obliging men to profess one thing while being another, is psychological torment. The denial of clergyrsquos humanity and self-expression is as cruel as anything the Inquisition devised. If the Vatican could bring itself to accept homosexuality, and gay marriage, and a non-celibate priesthood, it would be a truly Christian act.Read more: Cardinal Keith OBrien asked for forgiveness

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-locarno-in-glasgow
story: WErsquoVE decided to have one farinaceous main course at Locarno to keep down the total cost because the other mains are so expensive: pound. to pound.. I instantly exclude the ldquorissottoat pound. and pound.. Experience tells me that bad spelling often augurs bad cooking.With just a hint of a shoulder-shrugging ldquowhat do you expect me to do about it  attitude, our waiter breaks the news that all four, yes four, ravioli dishes listed on the menu are not available.So we alight on cacio e pepe, Romersquos favourite pasta, where the art is to leave just enough cooking water for the pasta to form a sauce when fresh Pecorino and ground black pepper is added.Therersquos confusion. Our waiter mishears: he thinks we want the catch of the day , so maybe the chef was flustered.Even so, Locarnorsquos clueless attempt at this classic would surely be greeted with derision in its home city: over-boiled spaghetti, so dry that it forms a mat, further clumped together by the plasticity of its cheese veneer, and not a speck of black pepper in sight.Seriously, I could use this sticky mass, Marx Brothers fashion, as a projectile. And pound for something parents might complain aboutserved as a school meal  What planet are they on here Irsquod say Locarno trades on its atmosphere, sort of swanky, clubby, with a bit of a Jazz Age vibe, white linen, classy chandeliers, black and white photos.The menu, like the pricing, is all over the place, a wacky compilation of everything from creamed Jalapentildeo chive soup and steak tartare to mince and tatties and controversial foie gras. Itrsquos an unhappy hybrid of Italian, French, and s Taste of Tartan.My first and only satisfactory dish here is caponata. It judges the tricky sweet-sour balance well the onions, celery and aubergines melt.Cock-a-leekieis disastrous, a murky broth with no chicken taste, mushy leeks cooked to khaki, vapid potatoes, dry chicken breast.Our waitress takes it away less than half-eaten without askingeverything is all right. Thatrsquos telling. Maybe she knows better than to ask for fear of a negative response.Irsquom one of relatively few people who actually enjoys calfrsquos liver, providing itrsquos properly cooked, but Irsquom looking at a plateful that even fills me with dread.The liver is deadly plain, without the crustiness Irsquod expect from the promised pan-frying in butter. Its sauce, said to be raspberry vinegar and caramelised onions, tastes to me like the smell my oven makes when it needs a good clean.Mashed potatoes have nothing going for them ndash too dry, lumpy, no perceptible butteriness, and it would appear that the kitchenrsquos savoir-faire with kaleonly extends to boiling it.This is another dish with that somethingrsquos-got-burnt-on-to-the-oven- floor whf. Itrsquos cleared away, largely uneaten. Again, no one seems to want to knowwhy.I canrsquot wait to escape home nowbut a table of  ndash all men, business account, naturally ndash is slowing down the already struggling front of house thatrsquos trying to serve customers and set new tables.Irsquom amazed to see that Locarno isquite busy. For the le of me I canrsquot see why.Oh, that spelling. Cregraveme brucircleacutee is described as ldquodevine. The caramel top is fine, whatrsquos under it isnrsquot. Stf with starch, no presence of vanilla grains, no quality that suggests eggs or cream, this might as well be Birdrsquos custard.Fruit in the crumble ndash apple, mango, cranberries, blueberries, pineapple apparently ndash forms an undferentiated sweet base for a topping thatrsquos moredoughy flour than gritty crumble.That pervasive smelly oven aroma has impregnated it too. title: letters-a-u-turn-from-the-big-yin
story: However, many of those ludicrous inconsistencies and idiosyncrasies were drawn from what he often saw and exclaimed as "shortbread-tin" Scottishness and "tartan kitsch" as apparently exemplied by the likes of Harry Lauder, Andy Stewart, Jimmy Logan, Take the High Road and the White Heather Club. That these were soft targets made them no-less the bulls-eyes of Billys flourishes and, oh, along with The Big Yin, it was dficult not to roar with laughter at them, such was his delivery and imaginative flights of often-surrealistic fancies.But to many, perhaps not endowed with his keen,acerbic, sardonic sensibilities, they were hurtful parodies and pastiches of long-cherished good times, innocent, even naive memories of a world no longer current but still extant in the quiet minds eye of reminiscence.Which is why his fairly recent, ostensibly damascene, conversion to all things Scottish just sticks ever so slightly in the craw. From his knighthood from an Establishment to whom he ranks as a subject not an equal, through to his now-elevated position as Grand Marshal of New Yorks Tartan Day Parade along Manhattans Sixth Avenueit would appear that Sir Billy is now perfectly at ease with honours and commendations as a great Scot, notwithstanding his previously jaundiced views of his homeland. We all know that the past is, indeed, a foreign country and that they do things dferently there, but memories endure.Still, I suspect and hope it is nothing more than the inevitable mellowing of the years that has brought him round to a more sanguine view of Scotland and its peoples and wish him nothing but the best of health and fortune in his uncertain future.Gerard McCulloch,Moffat Wynd, Saltcoats.

title: theresa-may-insists-brexit-must-not-be-blocked
story: The Prime Minister is flying to Egypt for an EU-League of Arab States summit where she is expected to hold talks with key EU figures as she battles to break the deadlock in the Brexit talks.Downing Street has played down hopes of a breakthrough during the course of the two-day gathering in the Red Sea resort, despite the presence of major players including European Council president Donald Tusk.The Prime Minister is pressing for changes to the Northern Ireland backstop which she hopes will finally convince MPs to back her Withdrawal Agreement following last monthrsquos crushing Commons defeat.Ahead of her departure, No  released details of her speech to a closed meeting of the National Conservative Conventionin Oxford on Saturday, when she told supporters the Governmentrsquos focus on delivering Brexit must be ldquoabsolute.Her comments came after three pro-EU Cabinet ministers signalled they could back moves in Parliament to delay Britainrsquos withdrawal to prevent a ldquodisastrous no-deal break.The intervention by Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke led to calls for their resignations by furious Tory Brexiteers ndash comments said to have been echoed in private by some Cabinet ministers.Northern Minister John Penrose warned taking no-deal off the table could undermine Mrs Mayrsquos efforts to secure concessions on the backstop.ldquoIt could torpedo Brexit completely, leaving us in a lsquoHotel Calorniarsquo Brexit, where wersquod checked out but could never leave, he said in an article for The Sunday .ldquoWersquod have built an enormous elephant trap for ourselves, and therersquod be no way to climb out.MPs are preparing for a potentially crucial series of votes on Wednesday which could see Parliament seize control of the Brexit processMrs May cannot secure an agreement with Brussels by mid-March.However The Sunday Times reports the votes could now be shelved in the wake of the latest Cabinet isions.In a joint article, Work and Pensions Secretary Ms Rudd, Business Secretary Mr Clark and Justice Secretary Mr Gauke said it was clear a majority of MPs would back an extension to the Article  withdrawal process rather than see no deal.However in her address to the NCC, Mrs May insisted it is vital the Government maintains its focus as the negotiations reach their final stages.ldquoOur focus to deliver Brexit must be absolute.We must not, and I will not, frustrate what was the largest democratic exercise in this countryrsquos history, she said.ldquoIn the very final stages of this process, the worst thing we could do is lose our focus.With party loyalties strained to breaking point following the resignations of three Tory MPs to join a group of Labour defectors in the new Independent Group, Mrs May warned against more internal blood-letting.Anna Soubry, Heidi Allen and Sarah Wollaston all complained they had been targeted in their constituencies because of their pro-Remain views, in some cases by former Ukip members who had switched to the Tories.However Mrs May said: ldquoWe are not a party of purges and retribution. We called a referendum and let people express their views ndash so we should not be seeking to deselect any of our MPs because of their views on Brexit.ldquoOur party is rightly a broad church ndash on that and other issues. And we will only save our country from the threat of Jeremy Corbynwe remain one.On Wednesday, the Commons is expected to consider an amendment tabled by Labour MP Yvette Cooper and Conservative former minister Sir Oliver Letwin enabling the House to extend the Article  withdrawal processthere is no deal by mid-March.A similar amendment was defeated by MPs last month, but there is speculation that enough Tory rebels, alarmed that there is still no deal in place, could be prepared to back it this time round for it to pass.Downing Street has saidthere is no deal by Tuesday, the Prime Minister will at that point make another statement to the House and table an amendable motion to be debated and voted on the following day.However, it is unclear whether that will be enough to stave off a revolt by MPs alarmed at the prospect of no deal ndash including potential ministerial resignations.

title: ian-blackford-david-mundell-should-resign-if-there-is-a-no-deal-brexit
story: SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford wrote to Mr Mundell calling on him to back an extension of Article  in order to avoid the UK leaving the EU without a deal in place.The UK is due to depart on March , however there is no agreement at Westminster over a deal after Prime Minister Theresa Mayrsquos proposals were rejected.Mr Blackford suggested in his letter to the Scottish Secretary that he should publicly threaten to quit the Cabinetthe UK Government is prepared to allow a no-deal Brexit.The SNP MP also referred in his letter to a report published on Thursday by Scotlandrsquos top economic adviser which suggested that a no-deal scenario could result in a recession worse than .####### A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit could mean:# % drop in GDP# -% drop in Scottish exports## Net migration turns negative#zwj# Unemployment rising by ,# Recession in Read the @scotgov Chief Economistrsquos report here: https:t.co vnaPsmPf pic QrAAblYmVmdash The SNPFebruary , Mr Blackford said: ldquoCrashing out of the EU with either Theresa Mayrsquos bad deal, or with no deal at all, is a  choice that would be disastrous for Scotland ndash destroying jobs, damaging living standards, and leaving the whole country poorer and worse off.ldquoTime is running out and the only way to prevent a bad deal for Scotland is to extend Article , and put the brakes on Brexit, to find a credible solution that protects jobs and the economy.ldquoScotland did not vote for Brexit, and we must not be dragged out of the EU against our will. It is time that the Scottish Secretary actually did his job for once by standing up for Scotlandrsquos interests.ldquoDavid Mundell must finally back SNP calls to extend Article , and make it clear that he will not serve in a UK government that is willing to impose a no-deal Brexit on Scotland.ldquoWestminster is failing Scotland. If the UK parliament continues to ignore our wishes and work against our interests, then it is clearer than ever that our interests can only be protected with independence.The Scottish Secretary has previously suggested to MPs that the best way to avoid no-deal Brexit would be to vote for the Prime Ministerrsquos deal.A UK Government source said: ldquoThis is gross hypocrisy from the SNP. The SNP lrmare doing their best to bring about a no deal, despite knowing the damage that would do to Scotland. They are only interested in their own isive, nationalist agenda, not what is best for Scotland.

title: i-wont-allow-brexit-vote-to-be-frustrated-theresa-may-promises-tories

In the very final stages of this process, the worst thing we could do is lose our focus.But after the resignations of three Tory MPs to join a group of Labour defectors in the new Independent Group, Mrs May said there should be no moves to deselect MPs because of their views on Brexit.Anna Soubry, Heidi Allen and Sarah Wollaston all complained they had been targeted in their constituencies because of their pro-Remain views, in some cases by former Ukip members who had switched to the Tories.However Mrs May said: ldquoNo-one gets more frustrated than I do when people vote against the whip, particularly given the tight Parliamentary arithmetic that we face.ldquoBut we are not a party of purges and retribution. To listen to their reasons, evenwe disagree with them. To explain politely where we think theyrsquore wrong.ldquoTo respect the sincerity of their decision, evenwe regret it. title: shamima-begum-i-regret-speaking-to-the-media
story: The teenager, who fled London aged  to join Islamic Statersquos self-proclaimed caliphate in Syria, has said she wants toto the UK with her newborn son.Ms Begum, who has had her British citizenship revoked, was one of three schoolgirls to leave Bethnal Green to join the terror cult in  and resurfaced heavily pregnant at a Syrian refugee camp last week.Speaking to The Sundayfrom the al-Hol camp in Syria, Ms Begum said: ldquoThey are making an example of me. I regret speaking to the media. I wish I had stayed low and found a dferent way to contact my family. Thatrsquos why I spoke to the newspaper.The Home Secretary revoked Ms Begumrsquos British citizenship in a move only permissible under international lawit does not leave the inidual stateless.It was speculated that Ms Begum, who is of Bangladeshi heritage, may have citizenship there but Bangladeshrsquos minister of state for foreign affairs Shahriar Alam denied this.Her family have written to the Home Secretary asking for his help to bring her newborn son to Britain.The letter to Sajid Javid said the baby boy was a ldquotrue innocent who should not ldquolose the privilege of being raised in the safety of this country.Her sister Remu Begum, writing on behalf of the family, asked how they could help the Home Secretary ldquoin bringing my nephew home to us.The family said they have had no contact with Ms Begum and had only learned she had given birth to a boy through media reports.They made clear that they were ldquoshocked and appalled at the ldquovile comments Ms Begum had recently made to the media.Mr Javidrsquos removal of her citizenship came amid heated debate over whether the teenager should be able toto the UK after she was found in a Syrian refugee camp with the terror grouprsquos reign nearly over.While many do not want to see Ms Begumto the UK, others have argued she should face prosecution for her actions, and attempts at deradicalisation.The Begum familyrsquos lawyer Tasnime Akunjee said she was born in the UK, has never had a Bangladeshi passport and is not a dual citizen, which was confirmed by the Bangladeshi minister.

title: we-must-support-government-through-brexit-insists-micheal-martin
story: Micheal Martin said members want the Fine Gael-led Government gone, but they refuse to expose the country to the ldquomassive risk of having no ing administration in the midst of Brexit.The Cork South Central TD made the comments during his presidential speech to his partyrsquos national conference in Citywest, Dublin, on Saturday night.Huge cheers and applause as @MichealMartinTD takes to the stage in Citywest for his presidential address #FFAF @PA pic KpLltHjmdash Michelle DevaneFebruary , Mr Martin said: ldquoIn normal times there would be no question about what should happen to this Government, but we have to accept the harsh reality of this very moment.ldquoIreland faces a genuinely historic threat from Brexit and it has to have a government in placewe are to have any chance of limiting its damage.ldquoEvery one of our members wants to get out on the doorsteps and sell a message of what a new government can do for our country.ldquoItrsquos a dficult decision for us, but itrsquos the right decision and it reinforces the fact that Fianna Fail is putting the national interest first.Fianna Fail re-entered into a confidence-and-supply arrangement with the Government last year. By doing so, it ensured the continuation of the Fine Gael-led minority Government.But in recent weeks as controversy over the spiralling overruns of the National Childrenrsquos Hospital became known, many party members voiced displeasure that they are continuing to back the Government.Mr Martin criticised the Government over homelessness, housing and health issues, saying that at a time when real leadership is needed the Government is ldquoout-of-touch and ldquochronically incapable of delivering plans.He also criticised Sinn Fein for ldquojumping up and down every day calling for ldquoeverything to be collapsed.He said: ldquoThey collapsed the Assembly and government in Northern Ireland over two years ago, causing huge damage and leaving the anti-Brexit majority at the mercy of anti-Europe parties.ldquoWersquoll take no lectures from them about the national interest when  times out of , they put their party and movementrsquos interests first.He blamed the DUP and Sinn Fein for the decline in the political situation in Northern Ireland.ldquoEveryone knows that the core issue has been with the DUP and Sinn Fein, who ran the Executive like a closed cartel looking after their own, he said.Fianna Faacuteil leader #@MichealMartinTD# told delegates that his party had to back the government as the country faces the historic threat of #Brexit #FFAF @PA pic DjaAlYbqvmdash Michelle DevaneFebruary , Mr Martin added that a new agenda for development is needed on both sides of the border, and that is why Fianna Fail had decided to enter a new partnership with the SDLP.ldquoWorking together we can help provide the new agenda which is so desperately needed both North and South, he said.It was Fianna Failrsquos first conference since the party announced a new partnership with the SDLP in January.SDLP leader Colum Eastwood earlier gave an address to the delegates at the day-long event in the Citywest Hotel which was dominated by Brexit and housing issues.On his arrival at the conference, Mr Martin said a new political agenda is required in Northern Ireland.He said he believes a new middle ground is emerging in the region that is not obsessed with constitutional issues and instead wants to see the institutions of the Good Friday Agreement ing.ldquoThe sensible thing for us is to work with the SDLP who are routed in the northhellip but work with them on a policy agenda in terms of that bringing new ideas and approaches, he said.
