title: former-priest-cancel-celibacy-vows-to-solve-churchs-culture-of-secrecy
story: Alex Walker, founder of the Advent group which helps priests thinking of leaving the church, said removing the celibacy vow would solve many of the issues around secret relationships within the church.However, allowing priests to have sex, get married and have families would open a "Pandoras box" and force the church to address issues it doesnt necessarily condone, he said.Mr Walker, who himself left the church in the s over the issue of celibacy and is now married, said: "The Catholic Church will not want to talk about numbers [of priests with children]. Even the number of priests who have resigned the ministry, or those who have requested dispensation for clerical celibacy, those numbers are not forthcoming from the Vatican."That would help with the conversation about whether celibacy is working for the majority of Catholic priests. Clearly we know it isnrsquot."Now that we have the gay debacle as well ndash there are a number of gay priests in the priesthood, and that needs to be acknowledged instead of covered up."All of this is about keeping the lid on Pandorarsquos box because once you allow priests to marry, then we get into the situation of priestsrsquo marriages breaking down, wanting orce, wanting to remarry. How can you keep the lid on that reality which the church doesnrsquot accept or condone  That is why this control of the celibacy rule for priests is key."Mr Walker explained that another reason why many priests may want to keep the fact they have children a secret is because many are ill-equipped to deal with secular le.He said: "When I left the ministry I had something like pound in my bank account. You are in a situation where you are frozen by fear [at the thought of] leaving to start a new le in the secular world."Priests are worried about security. Nine times out of  they wonrsquot have any money behind them unless theyrsquove been left a legacy from their parents, or perhaps parishioners. If they donrsquot have finances behind them then they will be reliant on the diocese renting them a property and perhaps giving them a stipend each month, which wonrsquot be a great deal."Depending on their age they have to think about employment, what do they do for a job  How do they earn their keep "It also means that they lose their status,there is still a status, for being a Roman Catholic priest. That all goes overnight as well and then they have to face up to their responsibilities which they have never really had to experience before."They have been completely sheltered in this cocoon - living in the presbytery, having their bills paid for, people treating them with deference. They would risk losing credibility amongst their own colleagues and companions too."Therersquos a lot going on there."At the end of the day, they still have fathered children and they should be the number one priority. The church should make it the number one priority for the priest also."A brief history of celibacy in the Catholic ChurchCatholic priests were not always required to be celibate, with several of the Apostles known to be married according to biblical accounts.The very first Pope, Saint Peter, was married and there are ious accounts of priests and popes throughout the ages discussing the issue of celibacy in letters and correspondence.Clement of Alexandria, a prominent theologian who died in AD, wrote: "The church fully receives the husband of one we whether he be priest or deacon or layman, supposing always that he uses his marriage blamelessly, and such a one shall be saved in the begetting of children.By AD, the first written requirement was made for those looking to join the priesthood to be celibate, and in  AD, Pope Gregory VII ruled that married priests were not allowed to say mass or carry out s.In , an ecumenical council for the Catholic church made celibacy mandatory for western clergy.In , Pope Francis said he would consider the possibility of allowing married men to join the priesthood, which is set to be discussed further this year.

title: spring-comes-early-at-scotlands-most-exotic-garden
story: Warmed by the Gulf Stream and protected from winterrsquos blast, the exotic plants of Logan Botanic Garden have always defied the harshest Scottish weather to blossom and flourish against the odds.Just  miles south of Stranraer, itrsquos where the tree fernsrsquo dainty fronds dance in the breeze, giant rhubarb leaves bigger than beach umbrellas create a tunnel to walk through and palm trees that could have come straight from a Calornian bouled thrive all year round.They can cope with the sprinkling of morning frost thatrsquos left some plants sparkling under the winter sun, says Loganrsquos curator Richard Baines. Instead, weeks of mild winter weather have taken a toll, creating confusion that has seen some plants burst into le and blossom weeks earlier than normal.ldquoLots of flowers, including some of the gardenrsquos camellia, are in full flower already, he says. ldquoThatrsquos a lot earlier than normal.One iety in particular, Mary Christian, with rich, glossy, dark green foliage and flowers of dazzling bright pink petals that hug a bouquet of delicate yellow stamen, has erupted in colour several weeks earlier than normal.ldquoItrsquos in full flower at the moment and normally that wouldnrsquot happen [for a few weeks yet], adds Baines.An early spring seemed on the cards as far back as mid-December when he spotted the first snowdrops carpeting the gardenrsquos woodland area ndash nearly two weeks earlier than expected.Throughout winter, the temperature at Logan hasnrsquot dipped below -.#c. Apart from a couple of stormy days which claimed a handful of victims, therersquos been little to send Loganrsquos exotic residents into a terribly deep sleep.ldquoI walked the garden over Christmas and counted  dferent plants in flower, Baines says. ldquoThey are definitely ahead of where they should be.ldquoOne member of staff has been here for over  years and remembers lsquoproperrsquo winters, when the whole place used to be cold and covered in frost.ldquoBut now we can grow plants which are fairly tender and can take just a little frost and they are doing fine outside.For gardeners across Scotland keeping watch for the first tentative green sprout of a crocus or bluebell, this subtle sht is not great news.A mild winter and early spring play havoc with the natural cycle of garden insects. Ladybirds may emerge from hibernation early and ready to feast on aphids only to find the cupboard bare, while a sudden cold snap could be disastrous for fragile flora.ldquoThere can be opportunity, adds Baines. ldquoMilder winters mean we can grow a wider range of plants. But the opposite is that in the last two decades you have probably had more pests and disease entering the world of horticulture than in the last two centuries.ldquoSudden oak death is pretty prominent, and one or two pests are much more prevalent because of the mild conditions.Itrsquos a clear sign ndashany were needed ndash of the battle faced by the natural world, one element of which was highlighted earlier this month when scientists warned that a global scientic review of insects had indicated they could become extinct within a century.The study, by University of Sydney, found % of all insect species are in decline. Their loss, it warned, would spark a ldquocatastrophic collapse in the worldrsquos ecosystems.ldquoQuite often therersquos a lot of mention of birds, animals and insects, but no mention of plants, he says, pointing out the risk to plantstherersquos no insects to pollinate. ldquoItrsquos always the cuddly, furry things that get the mention, but therersquos a whole ecosystem out there. When one part of the ecosystem falls down, therersquos a knock-on effect.But eveneverything in the global garden isnrsquot terribly rosy, therersquos much at Logan ndash one of four botanical gardens across Scotland that come under the umbrella of the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh ndash that is, at least, blooming.Last year, more than , visitors made the journey to the Rhins of Galloway on Scotlandrsquos southwestern tip ndash closer, as the crow flies, to the Isle of Man than it is to Glasgow, and further south than Newcastle.There they breathed in the scent from more than  species of New Zealand and Australian eucalyptus at the gardenrsquos Tasmanian Creek, marvelled at -year-old tree ferns that tower four metres tall, and the curious ldquofilo pastry tree, Polylepis australis, which sheds layers of its bark in a bid to capture warm air and protect itself from the cool breezes of its native Andes mountains.In spring and summer, the mountain rhododendrons compete for attention with exotic blooms from the Canary Islands, Australia, South Africa and Chile the  species of palms ndash some over  years old ndash evoke beach le in sunny climes rather than the southwestern tip of Scotland.There are more than  species of wild flora ndash foxgloves, irises and wild grasses ndash carpeting the ground, lilies thrive on the walled gardenrsquos pond and the carbon-neutral Victorian-style greenhouse contains South American gems rarely seen in the UK.Where  could you find a driveway stretching a quarter-of-a-mile thatrsquos lined with  cabbage plants ldquoPeople are blown away by the exoticness of the place, itrsquos like an island with sea on both sides, says Baines, who was so enchanted by Logan as a child that he went on to study horticulture and follow in the footsteps of famous plant explorers like George Forrest, trekking to foreign lands in search of rare specimens.Later this year, Logan will be the focus for a series of celebrations to mark  years since it was handed to the nation.Its roots stretch much further ndash the McDouall family was granted lands in the area by John Balliol in the late th century and built a castle. Destroyed in the th century, a small stump remains within Loganrsquos walled garden.Fascination with exotic plants erupted in the th century, fuelled by explorers who ventured around the world in search of unusual species. The McDouall familyrsquos fascination with what it found and its estatersquos mild climate were a perfect match.Soon the first eucalyptus trees in Scotland were planted in the grounds, and peat bogs dug into terraces to nurture primulas.The estate was gted to the nation in November  and passed to the Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh. Now, as well as being the arearsquos prime tourist attraction, itrsquos a base for horticultural study and conservation.New plants are arriving all the time. Later this year, Baines is heading on a plant expedition to Vietnam, in search of new species and to help secure the future of others.ldquoPlants are disappearing very quickly there through the impact of man, he explains.ldquoMany of these plants are very small and very fragile. A good example is a rhododendron called Kanehirae from north Vietnam."We did a survey five years ago and found the plant at Logan was the only one left in world."We propagated it, and circulated it around other botanic gardens.ldquoItrsquos not possible to undo whatrsquos been done to its native habitat, he adds. ldquoBut we can use our expertise so itrsquos not the end.

title: catholic-church-faces-mounting-pressure-to-help-traumatised-scots-children-of-priests
story: One organisation which is supporting Scots whose fathers are clerics says people are left scared and traumatised by their secretive upbringings, and feel as though the church is trying to pretend they donrsquot exist.Some have even had to sign confidentiality agreements to hide their paternal identities, according to Coping International, which advocates for children of priests.Children have also been sent to Scotland from Ireland and England as a way of keeping them hidden from parish communities which may find out about their parentage.The impact on those involved is severe and detrimental, according to campaigners, who describe their treatment and lack of acknowledgement as ldquoclerical abuse.The Catholic church in Scotland has admitted it has no idea how many Scottish priests, or those working in Scotland, have fathered children.A spokesman has also compared the situation to office workers having extramarital affairs, and said the church as an employer wouldnrsquot necessarily have to get involved.It comes after secret Vatican guidelines emerged this week for priests who father children, but the church has refused to release the documents or explain what advice they contained.Vincent Doyle, founder of support organisation Coping International, has blasted Scottish bishops for failing to get to grips with the scale of the issue, and said more needs to be done to support women and prieststhey find they are expecting a baby.Irish psychotherapist Doyle set up Coping International after he found out a priest he believed was his godfather was actually his biological dad. He said he is currently supporting several Scots between  and  whose fathers are priests, who, he said, have been left scarred by their covert parentage and are afraid to speak out.However, he stressed that the actual number of children, men and women across the globe whose fathers are Scottish priests, or who live in Scotland, is likely to be much higher.Sonflowers, a support group for women who have had relationships with priests, previously reported that it had been inundated with calls from Scottish women claiming they were having relationships with priests and in some cases were pregnant by them.The organisationrsquos founder said in  she had hoped to set up a specically Scottish group to deal with the influx of calls but faced opposition to even advertising her service in churches or bulletins across the country.Doyle said: ldquoWe are supporting eight Scottish people. Eight may seem like a small number to many, but for those eight people their lives have been hugely affected.ldquoThey have been hidden, they have had confidentiality agreements too. They are scared.ldquoWe have one Scottish woman we are working with who was fathered by an Irish priest. They moved to Scotland and hid her there and she has hidden ever since. She doesnrsquot know what to do or how to bring it up.ldquoThese people are terried. One guy I know has psychosis, hersquos on the verge of schizophrenia.ldquoWe have a lot of kids also from Ireland and England sent to Scotland, who were adopted but now through things like ancestry and DNA matching sites they are finding out their roots and what actually happened.ldquoThere are around  priests in Scotland at the minute, but how many men have been ordained in Scotland or how many Scottish men have been missionary priests over the last  years  That is where the real question is.ldquoWhen you take that into consideration,only % of those priests fathered children, yoursquore talking about a surprising number.ldquoOn a global level, we know about , children in this position and that is only the ones we know about, itrsquos a hugely conservative estimate.A Catholic church spokesman told The Herald on Sunday there was no evidence of ldquosignicant numbers of children fathered by priests in Scotland, and compared priests having relationships to an office worker having an extramarital affair with a colleague.He said in both scenarios, vows would have been broken but it would not necessarily be the responsibility of the employer to get involved.When pressed, he admitted the church had no idea of the numbers and he had only heard of one such case before, but insisted that Scottish bishops would support prieststhey came to them to ask for help.The spokesman said: ldquoIn the case of a priest who has fathered a child, it is not possible to rule out any possible responses to these situations.ldquoA decision to remain or leave the priesthood would be made on its merits in each case.ldquoThere are no central records of such cases and while the church would not necessarily be aware of them, there is no suggestion of signicant numbers in this country.He also said there had been several priests who had left the priesthood to pursue relationships, and in his view there was no stigma around the issue.He said: ldquoIf a priest was to say to his bishop that he had fathered a child and, whether he wanted help to leave the priesthood and set up as a father or to remain in the priesthood but be able to support the child, the church would do whatever they could to support either of those options.ldquoEvery year a number [of priests] leave to get married. One left from Glasgow last year, for example. In the past that would have been seen as much more scandalous and a stigma. The view now is that the church is grateful for the service that you have given.Doyle has criticised the remarks and called for the church in Scotland to take the lead in finding and supporting people fathered by priests, and to understand why many priests do not disclose they have children.He said: ldquoI absolutely condemn the use of that world lsquosignicantrsquo in any regard. This is clerical abuse. If there are only five or  children in Scotland, so what  Quantity never should come in to pastoral care.ldquoIn order for this issue to be addressed we have to do away with moralistic audacious statements and look at this practically and also empower the woman. If you empower the mother and say lsquoyou are far from alone, you donrsquot need to be afraidrsquo, it would help, instead of the woman being told they are the only person in Scotland who is in this situation, and they must keep quiet in order for the priest to be able to support them and not lose their job.ldquoI would go back to the Catholic bishops in Scotland and ask them what constitutes a signicant number. We are working with eight people ndash is that insignicant  I donrsquot know the full number of children of priests in Scotland, but neither do the bishops.ldquoThe Catholic church should be willing to bend over backwards for one child so this whole thing of lsquosignicancersquo is hugely disrespectful, harmful and what they are trying to do is make this inauthentic.ldquoThere are children of priests the same as there are children of plumbers, fishermen, hairdressers ... they are out there.ldquoAnd it is never going to stop. Unless they stop ordaining heterosexual males it will happen. They canrsquot quanty it and they canrsquot address it.ldquoThe church have tried to dismiss child sexual abuse initially by saying its unquantiable, itrsquos the same thing.If you have been affected by this story please contact Hannah Rodgerathannah.rodger@heraldandtimes

title: in-pictures-homes-transformed-into-magnificent-galleries-at-window-wanderland
story: An annual tradition, locals decorated their windows with colourful, ornate designs.One home even renamed itself the Bungo Jukebox, decorating every window with a musical theme.Another featured a controversial message about the recent Glasgow School of Art fire.Hundreds walked the streets and marvelled at the fantastic displays, while others attended film screenings at a pop-up cinema.The Pollywood community cinema showed Rear Window by Alfred Hitchcock along with several other flicks throughout the evening.

title: rab-mcneil-concentrate-on-your-allotment-jeremy-theres-plenty-of-horse-manure-in-parliament
story: All I know is that centre parties are always rubbish and are only supported by ditherers who canrsquot make up their mind between left and right, and who fall for all the tripe about a ldquonew politics espoused by people steeped in the old politics and, more importantly, desperate to keep their seats.No, I am more interested in the much-reported fact that when the splitters were preparing to leave his party, Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn went down to his allotment to lt some tatties. Irsquom quite sure that, in many ways, Jeremy would be a disaster for the country ndash as, to be fair, would they all ndash but there are some things I canrsquot help liking about the man.Hersquos done good work in ing the otherwise pointless party to its socialist roots .Anyway, as news of the allotment scandal broke, right-wing papers screamed that hersquod ldquolost the plot and even that he was ldquoin a hole. Disgraceful. But, oddly enough, that very same day, one such publication coincidentally ran another story about GPs prescribing allotments to patients suffering from stress or heart scares or loneliness.Irsquom not sure how it benefits the latter, unless one is expected to talk to onersquos plants. I have tried this, and the downside is that it is frankly a one-sided conversation. Itrsquos pretty much the same with the garden birds, though sometimes they do tweet back and, once, Irsquom sure I heard a tit say, ldquoShut up, beardie!However, I do back the idea of allotments being good for the soul. The happiest times of my le coincided with having allotments. During one particular period, I wrote in the morning, tended my allotment in the afternoon, and sorted mail for the GPO in the evenings, back in the days when I could truly claim to be a man of letters.I was poor but as happy as Larry, whoever he is, and remembered that Karl Marx had pretty much described such a le under communism in his famous book, ldquoDas Allotments. A particularly pleasant memory is of spreading rotten seaweed on the soil and a blackbird being so transported with delight that, after scoffing his fill of wee microbes on the maritime manure, he came and sat and warbled on the toe of my boot as I lay back contented with my labours.Alas, every time it came time for cultivation, I had to abandon the plot, as I am one of those fellows who can never settle and is always moving on, usually with disastrous consequences.In my lectures to young people about le, I always tell them:. Do not stand out from the crowd.. Donrsquot go anywhere. I didnrsquot get where I am todayby going anywhere, and. As for crowds, yoursquore best not getting involved with them at all.The same goes for political parties. Therersquos a growing feeling that such a system of agglomerated ndash and that really, inexplicably feels like the right word ndash iniduals is done. I never understood it anyway, particularly having a slate of policies that you had to agree with in full: ldquoI am pro-gay rights therefore I am anti-nuclear.My advice to Jeremy is to spend more time on his allotment and less time in Parliament. There are enough vegetables already in the latter. And the place is filled to the rafters with manure.If Ikea made history ...ITrsquoS so common for historians to rewrite history these days that they should probably be described as rehistorians.Itrsquos terribly tedious, as it overturns the ldquotruths we were taught as nippers, making us doubt everything we are told and take up careers in journalism.However, I must say I was taken with the idea of a ldquoNeolithic Ikea, which suggested that folks in the Flintstone Era waddled around chaotic quarries and chose large items to take home.This, we are told, is what happened at yonder Stonehenge, suggesting that the whole thing was a kind of flatpack assembled at home on the Salisbury Plain by men reading instructions consisting largely of illustrations, as seen in the Lascaux caves .Maybe that explains why the stones are all wonky and there are bits missing. Mind you, itrsquos not known how they got the stones from Neolithikea back up the road.As many of you who have tried cramming a flatpack wardrobe into a Nissan Micra will have discovered, this is by far the worst part of the whole business.The best job on Middle EarthI HAVE discovered the dream job: sitting in a bunker near LA, writing the script for Amazonrsquos planned Lord of the Rings prequel.Way back in the last century, Hollywood used to hire writers to work in little rooms in special writersrsquo blocksand just come up with ideas and scripts. Most of it never amounted to anything, and nor was much expected, but they were paid vast salaries to tootle away at their typewriters.The incomparable PG Wodehouse was one such, but I think he found it rather dull and unfulfilling, I wouldnrsquot. Me! Me! Irsquoll do that.One problem at the Tolkien writing bunker is that the writers are kept under lock and key, to stop any script leaks getting out. I think the writers are let out from time to time, and itrsquos suggested that itrsquos as much to keep spies out as scribblers in.Added to which, I bet the foodrsquos good and the rewards spectacular. Please: me! I know the dference between the Vanyar and the Noldor elves. I know Darth Vaderrsquos the bad guy. Therersquos also a Wookie, right

title: garfield-phones-chaplin-headlines-smart-fridges-and-the-nearly-greatest-its-almost-worth-not-waving-a-flag-about
story: Itrsquos a mystery of the deep which has baffled the finest French maritime scientists and climatologists for more than  years. Where do these Garfield telephones which keep being washed up on the coast of Brittany come from One theory is that a container of them fell overboard in the Channel some time in the s and currents have pushed them southwards since. However, such a loss has never been reported to the maritime authorities, which may not be unusual as hundreds of containers slip overboard each year, but as owners are responsible for recovery costs they often donrsquot admit to it.Containers go straight down to the seabed and break open over time, so there will be thousands of them down there with goodness knows what inside. Lord Lucan possibly.These troublesome and persistent yellow and black Garfields, moulded as the cartoon character, are made of apparently indestructible plastic and they donrsquot float, so they have inched ndash or millimetred ndash towards France, pushed by the currents for three decades to the beaches. And, no, they donrsquot still work.Itrsquos possible ndash my theory ndash that the washed-up ones are pirate copies of the real thing, given therersquos no serial number, stamp or other identier on them. Certainly another damaging,rather quirky, reminder of the plastic pollution in our oceans and seas.Headline news on your doorstepLike all good, lasting myths the one about the Press And Journal and the Titanic ndash ldquoAberdeen man drowns at sea ndash has been impossible to scotch, even after more than  years ... and even although it isnrsquot strictly, or even a little, accurate. In fact, the headline in the Aberdeen Daily Journal, as it then was, blandly stated: ldquoAberdeen people on the Titanic. But the myth will never perish.I can vouch, however, that when commemorating Charlie Chaplin the headlinesaid ldquoNairn was famous comedianrsquos favourite holiday resort. I was in Nairn at the time, doorstepping a paedophile priest, so I swear itrsquos true.Great headlines are immortal. A favourite of mine, long ago fromwhen it was worth reading, was ldquoQueen in riot at Palace. Sadly not about Her Maj and Phil having a bust-up over his wayward driving, but Scottish forward Gerry Queen in a punch-up at Crystal Palace. Then therersquos ldquoSuper Caley go ballistic Celtic are atrocious.In the spirit of the PJ and Titanic, here are a few competitors from the Oldham Evening Chronicle, which died in August ndash the paper, not the headlines ndash but has now been resuscitated in an online version. ldquoCat saves owners as fire grips armchair, ldquoBraking bus shakes children, but the real successor to the loon drowning, or not, in the Atlantic surely is ldquo die in Bay blaze but Oldham man is safe.The new digital version its trying hard. ldquoOldham woman hit by tram at Oldham Mumps, it reported during the week. The tram is said to be recovering.Love in a cold climateIf yoursquore looking for a partner and yoursquore too hip, old, or ugly to try Tinder or Grindr then therersquos a cool new dating app that has just launched. Cool  Itrsquos pure Baltic.It has the same swipe technology used by other sites but this one shows pictures of the contents of your fridge. Apparently, you can find a love matchall you have in the icebox is out-of-date milk, the remains of an Indian takeaway and a couple of cans of beer. Well, perhaps not. It didnrsquot work for me.This is, of course, a pretty pathetic, publicity-seeking wheeze by Samsung to sell its Family Hub fridges, which are wi-connected and come with an internal camera. Oh, and a price tag of around pound,. The company claims that you can tell a lot about the personality of someone by judging the contents of their fridge, which, unfortunately in my case, may be true.But why anyone would want to reveal their unpleasant secret, selfie-ing their mouldy comestibles while standing in the kitchen, and organising their le on the touchscreen of a fridge large enough to house Kathy Bates, defeats me.When he became kingIt will be  years tomorrow that arguably the greatest sportsman of our times, the then Cassius Clay, aged , beat world heavyweight champion Sonny Liston, whose guts gave out and he retired on his stool at the start of the seventh round. In the run-up to the fight, where he was a - outsider, pundits chortled when Clay declared: ldquoI was born to be great. I am great and I will be greater ndash the greatest.Three years later, having proved it, and now Muhammad Ali, he was stripped of the title in his prime for refusing conscription to the Vietnam war, famously saying: ldquoMan, I ainrsquot got no quarrel with them Viet Cong, No Viet Cong ever called me a n****r. He was out of boxing for four-and-a-half years before his all-conquering .Will EU or wonrsquot EU We may or may not leave the EU at the end of next month but, according to a recent survey, one-third of the people in France and Germany already think we have gone. Perhaps wishful thinking  It is almost certain that we wonrsquot be participating in the May European elections and, according to surveys carried out in all  remaining countries, the far right is going to benefit from British absence.The far-right ENF groupwill be the main beneficiary, going from  seats to . This grouping hosts Marine Le Penrsquos National Rally party and the Italian League party of Matteo Salvini, up from six seats to .A VEXED QUESTIONUntil last week I didnrsquot know what a vexillologist was , or that there was a charity called the Flag Institute, which manages the UK Flag Registry. Nor did I know that East Lothian had recently had its flag design registered ndash it looks like a Lion Rampant in a box being struck by thunderbolts. Or the stushie over the Sutherland one. The original design, which was a swooping eagle in red and yellow against the same colours, counterchanged, in the background, roused the ire of the locals, with one of the objectors claiming in evoked communism .The Lord Lyon, who seems to have a say in these things, halted the process and a design was finally chosen, after a public vote. The final version looks like the kind of number stormtroopers wear on their arms, but apparently it evokes sunrises and sunsets ndash perhaps,yoursquove been poked in the eye with a flagpole. Thatrsquos a lot of not knowing by me to unfurl.All of which leads to the, perhaps unsurprising, news that the sales of Union Jacks have gone up  per cent in the last few months. I like the Banksy quote from his work, Wall And Piece: ldquoPeople who enjoy waving flags donrsquot deserve to have one.

title: cool-list-the-best-scottish-railway-journeys
story: Edinburgh to AberdourThink ldquotrains and ldquoScotland then let your mind come to rest on the third image that comes to you. OK, so right now yoursquore probably seeing the information board at Glasgow Queen Street with the words ldquocancelled and ldquodelayed sprinkled across it, so letrsquos skip that and try for the fourth image which, pun intended, is bound to be the Forth Bridge.Nothing  evokes the romance of rail travel quite like this wonder of Victorian engineering, and for a relatively modest fee ndash aticket from Edinburgh Waverley to Inverkeithing, the first stop on the north side of the estuary ndash you can enjoy not one but two trips across it.However, an even better idea is to stay on until Aberdour, where you can disembark at one of Scotlandrsquos prettiest stations, walk the few yards to one of its most interesting castlesand then stroll downhill to the sandy town beach. Glasgow to MallaigProperly referred to as the West Highland Line, this beguiling stretch of rail is now better known to millennials as the Harry Potter Line thanks to the spectacular Glenfinnan Viaduct which the Hogwarts Express crosses in the blockbuster films. As the train chugs its way northwest from Glasgow there are glimpses of Ben Nevis, Loch Shiel and Loch Eilt, and you may even catch sight of the isles of Rum, Eigg, Muck and Canna.The line crosses desolate Rannoch Moor and passes through Corrour, the highest mainline station in the UK, but it also serves coastal Arisaig, where anyone disembarking can enjoy some of the whitest sands in the world.The entire line is regularly voted one of the most scenic on the planet so itrsquos already deserving of its place in the Cool List, butyou want to go the whole Hogwarts then hop on board The Jacobite, the steam-hauled train which runs between Fort William and Mallaig. Leadhills to WanlockheadIf geographical trivia is your specialist subject at the local pub quiz then you donrsquot need telling that Wanlockhead is Scotlandrsquos highest village or that itrsquos located not in the Highlands but in the Lowther Hills in Dumfries and Gallowayrsquos Southern Uplands. If all that comes as news to you and you fancy a visit, donrsquot miss this treat. The railway is a narrow gauge and runs along the track bed of what was once a branch line on the Caledonian Railway to Wanlockhead from nearby Elvanfoot.It closed in  and shortly afterwards the lead mines it served were mothballed, so now the railway mostly pulls tourists along the kilometre or so between the two villages. Naturally, Wanlockhead also boasts Scotlandrsquos highest pub, the perfect place to read Robert Burnsrsquos poem Pegasus At Wanlockhead, written over a dram in another local hostelry as he waited for the horse of that name to have a shoe tended to by the village blacksmith. Inverness to WickKnown as the Far North Line for obvious reasons, this four-and-a-half-hour, -mile journey sees the train follow the coast for much of the way. Among the stops is one practically at the gates of the magnicent Dunrobin Castle, completed in the s at the behest of the owner who quite fancied having his own railway line. It required the say-so of Parliament but given that the owner was the Duke of Sutherland, the permissions werenrsquot too hard to get.Other highlights include Skibo Castle, Foulis Castle, the atmospheric peat bogsand the distilleries of Teaninich, Dalmore, Balblair, Whyte  Mackay , Glenmorangie , and, in Wick itself, Pulteney . Inverness to Kyle of LochalshIf yoursquore heading for Skye from the capital of the Highlands, then the so-called Kyle Line is the only way to travel. The line runs along the Beauly Firth, through Dingwall and on past villages such as Achnashellach, Achnasheen, Lochcarron and picturesque Plockton, where much-loved BBC drama Hamish Macbeth was filmed. Naturally there are great views of Skye itself at the end of the line but along the way yoursquoll also see the Torridon Peaks, Ben Wyvis, Loch Luichart and Loch Carron as well as some rugged Highland scenery. Aviemore to BroomhillThe route isnrsquot so much the treat here as the train itself because itrsquos on these  miles of restored track from the original Highland Railway Line that the Strathspey Steam Railway has run since it was brought back to le by a group of enthusiasts in . It runs between Aviemore stationrsquos  three and Broomhillrsquos Glenbogle station via Boat of Garten and when yoursquore not looking out of the window at the sceneryyoursquoll be looking around the old-style carriages or even down at your plate ndash the service offers all manner of dining experiences, from light lunches and afternoon teas to formal evening meals. Dufftown to KeithThis -mile line links the Moray towns of Keith and Dufftown, the self-styled ldquoWhisky Capital of the World . Predictably the line itself, once part of the Aberdeen to Elgin line, is known now as the Whisky Line and also bills itself the UKrsquos most northerly ldquoheritage railway. The rolling stock includes old commuter carriages from the s and s, and a dining coach which used to be part of the British Rail InterCity stock, but which has been repainted and renamed Spirit Of Dufftown. The line is closed for the winter and reopens on April . Borsquoness to Manuel JunctionOne of Scotlandrsquos most popular heritage railways, the Borsquoness and Kinneil Railway runs five miles between Borsquoness near Falkirk and Manuel Junction, via Kinneil and Birkhill. The views are pretty enough but again itrsquos the rolling stock which is the star.Among the favourites are  Neilson Reid locomotive Lord Roberts, which has been painted Thomas The Tank Engine blue, a set of s coaches in whatrsquos known as a ldquoblood and custard livery, and a pair of Caledonian coaches built in . Borsquoness is also home to the Museum of Scottish Railways, which houses historic locomotives, carriages, cranes, wagonsas well as shunting units, motorised trolleys and all manner of objects and archive stuff. Edinburgh to TweedbankThe Borders line, closed in  as part of the infamous Beeching cuts, reopened with no little fanfare in September  and reconnected the capital with the Borders towns of Galashiels and Melroseas well as Midlothian towns such as Dalkeith, Newtongrange and Gorebridge. The scenery is pleasant enough ndash go to the Highlandsyou want mountains and lochs ndash but the appeal of the Borders Railway, as itrsquos now known, lies in its ality and its historical importance: its rebirth brought a new dynamism and opportunity to a part of the country too often overlooked, and signicant numbers of tourists as well. Book lovers in particular have good reason to take the trip. Where  can you take a train which starts from a station named after a famous novel ndash Waverley, by Sir Walter Scott ndash and terminates close to the authorrsquos home, in this case Abbotsford, near Melrose  Milton of Crathes to Birkenbaud CrossingItrsquos only a mile of track along the now-disused Ballater to Aberdeen line, but as the name suggests the Royal Deeside Railway is steeped in history, thanks to the fact that for over a century, until its closure in , it was used by the royal family travelling to Ballater and from there to nearby Balmoral Castle. It was even used by ill-fated Russian tsar Nicholas II when he visited in .The original Crathes Castle station was built initially for the private use of the Laird of Crathes, and only later was the public allowed to use it. The Milton of Crathes station features a Victorian building but it came originally from Oldmeldrum and was sold to the Royal Deeside Railway for pound then transported to its new home in carefully labelled sections.The line has both steam- and diesel-hauled trains and among the former is the Thomas The Tank Engine-style Salmon. A sombre coda: the engine was named in commemoration of HMS Salmon, a submarine lost with all hands in . The line is closed for the winter and will reopen at Easter.How the Borders Railway creates a new future for Scotlands "forgotten" regionTravel: the West Highland Line

title: scotlands-money-are-we-spending-it-properly
story: Itrsquos two days before the Budget and Derek Mackay, Scotlandrsquos Finance Secretary, is sitting in his spartan ministerial office robustly defending his spending plans ndash while dealing with a nasty cold.Hersquos a man facing an almost impossible array of demands. Some of the brightest minds, and biggest voices, are calling for him to pull to the left, pull to the right, protect the poor, and boost business ndash all at the same time. Mackay ndash self-contained, confident and smartly dressed ndash may see himself as a steady pair of hands, but hersquod need the skill of a juggler to make everyone happy.At its heart, the Budget is redistributive ndash taking from the rich to provide services for the poor by widening the gap between how much higher earners pay in income tax in Scotland compared with the rest of the UK. Mackay has frozen the higher rate threshold at pound, in Scotland, while it will go up to pound, in the rest of the UK. However, everyone earning under pound, ndash % of taxpayers ndash will end up paying less income tax than in the rest of the UK.The spending plans also provide extra money for education , health , and infrastructure , and give new powers to councils to introduce a workplace car parking tax and a tourist tax. Local authorities get an extra poundm and can also increase council tax by up to .% rather than %.But what do the people who spend their lives studying the Scottish economy make of the Budget  Does the way Scotland spends its money work  Where could money be spent better  And what ideas might change the game when it comes to Scotland and out public services Some of the leading lights in Scottish public le give their views.PROFESSOR RONALD MACDONALDECONOMIST WITH THE ADAM SMITH BUSINESS SCHOOL AT GLASGOW UNIVERSITYRonnie MacDonald is happy to pay more tax, but he isnrsquot so happy with the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach to balancing the books. ldquoThe focus seems to be too much on spending ndash there isnrsquot so much emphasis on growing the economy, he says.About half the revenue raised comes from taxes, he says, and our ldquoeconomy is very skewed towards oil ndash a commodity in price decline. ldquoItrsquos a dangerous strategy for the long-term sustainability of public spending, MacDonald says.With limited borrowing powers, the Government has a choice between "growing the economy or spending less". The Government is following a Nordic-style model of public spending, he says.However, ldquothese Nordic countries grew their economies before making spending changes, we seem to be doing it the other way around.ldquoI think wersquoll ultimately have to cut spending, he adds. ldquoYou either prioritise and have a leaner mix now, or yoursquore forced to do it in the future ndash you could face much worse cuts in the future.Higher taxes in Scotland ldquomay well put off foreign firms thinking of investing in Scotland, he says. ldquoIf Irsquom a US-based company thinking of Scotland or the north of England, Irsquom going to go where the tax regime is more favourable to my employees. All in all itrsquos quite a dangerous game theyrsquore playing.Macdonald suggests a ldquorealignment from spending ldquotowards lowering business rates to encourage growth.A more erse economy would grow more quickly, says MacDonald, and provide the money needed for the ldquopublic provision the SNP wants to offer. Manufacturing around le sciences and new technology is one way forward.MacDonald suggests Scotland should follow the path of Australia ndash currently blazing a trail with the solar production of renewable hydrogen as a green energy source. Renewable hydrogen, says MacDonald, can be stored and shipped in liquid form. Given Scotlandrsquos wind and waves, wersquod be in a perfect position to exploit the new technology in the era of climate change.ldquoIt could be revolutionary, MacDonald says. ldquoIt could be as important as the discovery of oil ... it could lead to the reindustrialisation of Scotland.If the Government used public money to invest in the new technology ldquoit could create a sovereign wealth fund as the Norwegians did to use oil to pay for services.DAVE MOXHAMSTUC DEPUTY GENERAL SECRETARYldquoThe Budget is incredibly timid, says Moxham. ldquoWith the current ambition of a little bit more tax on middle- to higher-income earners, itrsquos quite impossible to fund the public services we need without the recognition that people on median and above incomes are going to have to pay more in taxation."We canrsquot pretend therersquos any mechanism for funding public services which doesnrsquot have that sort of ambition.ldquoItrsquos not enough to constantly use a Conservative Government as a comparator and say wersquore being slightly more progressive. Any party which aspires to say Scotland would be dferent under independence needs to be showing more now about what their commitment is to social justice.The STUC, says Moxham, would be ldquocomfortable with everyone above median income ndash about pound, ndash paying an extra penny in tax. ldquoThatrsquos small change. Itrsquos hardly bank-breaking, he adds.Spending needs to get smarter and more local too, Moxham says. Councils and council staff need more say in spending ndash as they understand the problems. ldquoTherersquos too much centralisation and not enough devolution to local authorities, he adds.He cites hospitals improving heart failure response times because ldquothe porters helped design the system of getting someone from the front steps to the operating theatre.ldquoWersquove had lots of reorganisation of the delivery of public services but these have tended to be executive-led, he says. Whatrsquos needed is getting the people who deliver the services ndash carers, nurses, teachers ndash to help design services. ldquoThe person who best knows how to organise a home care service is probably the home carer on the ground.The big idea that the STUC is investigating is a ldquouniversal basic infrastructure ndash where everyone has the guaranteed right to decent transport, housing, clinics and schools. Public spending priorities would be re-engineered around making sure every citizen had the basic infrastructure for a decent le.Small business bonus schemes are in the STUCrsquos sights. ldquoWe need a completely new approach to business tax giveaways, says Moxham. Investing in specic high-street regeneration schemes ldquois a far better way to rebuild our local high streets than the current approach where someone may need the boost, but others are using it to fund a second car.TRACY BLACKDIRECTOR OF CBI SCOTLANDIF the Government stimulates the white heat of technology it can fill its coffers with tax pounds and use the money to spend on the public services it wants ndash thatrsquos essentially Blackrsquos view.A no-deal Brexit could cost Scotland poundbn a year by , she says, and our demographics are going against us with a rapidly ageing population, so we need to start spending as smartly as we can. AI and automation could reduce costs. The elderly donrsquot have to travel to hospital when their blood pressure could be checked by remote monitoring. Investment in smart-ticketing and autonomous vehicles could help the high street.Glasgow may be a G hub, but connectivity needs improved across the country, as does infrastructure, Black says, so ldquowe get goods and people moving around more effectively.One big idea that Black is promoting is using national data to change how we spend public money. Data on the economy and population could be used by business ldquoto come up with really creative solutions around transport and health.The Scottish Government has done well so far supporting science and technology in business. Black says our pharma manufacturing sector is one of the most advanced in the world ndash itrsquos now the second-biggest spender on research and development, exports poundm in products, and has seen jobs rise by .%. The Medicines Manufacturing Innovation Centre in Renfrewshire was l funded by the Government and industry.Itrsquos this close working relationship between Government and industry that Black wants more of ndash but she feels there are ldquomixed messages when it comes to income tax, parking levies and the tourist tax. ldquoNone of these on their own are particularly crippling, but you put the whole package together and what sort of signal does that put out to inward investors PROFESSOR GRAEME ROYDIRECTOR OF THE FRASER OF ALLANDER INSTITUTE"THE debate around public spending collapses down into short-term political sound bites rather than more intelligent conversations," says Roy. "We see that every week at First Ministerrsquos Questions and in every manesto that every party produces."Parties obsess on issues like ", more nurses or , extra police officers" when they should be looking at outcomes ndash like extending le expectancy or making streets safer. It may be that spending more money on housing rather than nurses will improve le expectancy. Preventative measures ndash that improve health or cut crime ndash will save money in the long run."Simple metrics donrsquot do anything for the long-term delivery of better value for public services," Roy says. "Therersquos a fixation on targets and numbers when the evidence is that you should be bolder."He adds: "If wersquore thinking about long-term sustainability of public services what we need to do is reduce demand, not just keep increasing supply."Such a quantum sht in how we look at public spending would require political courage. Politicians are locked in short election cycles, while long-term preventative policies might take decades to show fruit, Roy says. Closing a hospital because it makes more sense to spend the money on nutrition for the young could lose a government an election, even though  years from now it might have improved health."Some of the delivery of public services is simply not going to be sustainable in the long run," Roy says. "Wersquove played with numbers where we think that on current projections NHS spending will within the next two or three years be pretty much % of the Scottish Budget. This will mean every other area in the public sector has to be squeezed ndash thatrsquos the sort of thing which I think will start to force more radical thoughts on how we deliver public services."JOHN DICKIEDIRECTOR, CHILD POVERTY ACTION GROUPDickie is clear that Scotlandrsquos public spending does not match the ambition of the Government when it comes to tackling child poverty. Targets have been set that less than % of children should be living in poverty by .With currently one in four Scots children in poverty ndash thatrsquos about , ndash to reach that target, says Dickie, "we need a substantial rethink of how we raise revenue and allocate resources to make sure those families on the lowest incomes can give children a decent start in le". Estimates show that one in three children could be in poverty within a few years.Dickie wants an "income supplement" to lt family finances to levels above the poverty line. The government is committed to introducing an income supplement by  ndash however, it hasnrsquot said how that will be delivered or how much it will be.The supplement needs brought in now, Dickie says. "Families canrsquot wait until ." He applauds policies like best start grants for families, and improvements in school clothing grants but says "none of this is on the scale to have the kind of substantive long-term impact to really change the trajectory of child poverty".Dickie would also like to see the Scottish Government act to top up child benefit by around pound, following cuts by the UK Government.Not tackling child poverty is a drain on the economy ndash with children more likely to get involved in crime, have poor health, and fewer job prospects. "The government needs to act with urgency," Dickie says. It needs to "recognise the value of the next generation" and invest.DEREK MITCHELLCHIEF EXECUTIVE, CITIZENS ADVICE SCOTLANDWHEN there are families going to foodbanks and receiving "cold bags" of shopping because their gas and electricity has been cut off ndash when % of people in "food poverty" are working ndash then for Mitchell "that doesnrsquot paint a picture of a society where everything is wonderful and great"."The simple matter is," he says, "that things are very dficult for lots of people and that doesnrsquot show any sign of abating."Public resources need to go to those most in need, Mitchell says. "Poor people donrsquot have a voice. Wersquove a debate at a political level. We talk about interest rates and mortgage rates, we donrsquot talk about household debt."Put simply: wersquore looking at things through the wrong end of the telescope. Get tougher with payday loan companies, force employers to pay decent wages, increase the funeral expense allowance, prioritise affordable rent ndash these are the levers of Government Mitchell wants to see pulled.DEREK MACKAYSCOTTISH FINANCE SECRETARYMACKAYrsquoS childhood shaped his politics. This is a man who didnrsquot grow up easy ndash raised in a council house, he even spent time in a homeless unit after a family break-up. He puts his le lessons into his policies ndash beliefs like ldquothe importance of community, kindness, treating others as you would be treated yourself.ldquoIrsquom very aware of chaotic lestyles, lack of opportunities, intergenerational poverty, he says. Mackay says he struck it lucky by entering politics and getting elected. It changed the direction of his le.Hersquos got a slick command of his portfolio and can rattle off statistics at a dizzying rate ndash but his Budget is assailed from all sides: itrsquos either a hit on the middle classes or it isnrsquot doing enough for the poor.Criticism doesnrsquot faze Mackay though ndash only once does he falter, and even then momentarily, when asked why the SNP needed the Greens to push them in a more progressive direction over policies like the parking levy.In his eyes, the Budget is about stability in the face of ldquocalamity at Westminster sustainability of public services, and stimulus for the economy.Mackay says preventative measures are built in when it comes to public health and early years ndash and the economy of the future is being looked after in terms of innovation on data and infrastructure. Direct investment in Scotland is second only to London, and research and development is at record levels. He makes much of new figures showing unemployment is at an all-time low.However, therersquos only so much the Government can do given the limited range of powers granted to a devolved administration, he says. ldquoWe can grow the economy as an independent countrywe have control of levers like immigration policy, and over a wider basket of taxation powers.Mackay described his current Budget as ldquofair and progressive in that it takes ldquoa bit more from the highest earning section of society. In the next financial year, he says, ldquo% of taxpayers will pay less tax, not more, on their current incomes, and itrsquos only those on or above pound, who will pay more.Itrsquos a ldquobalanced and moderate approach, he thinks. ldquoWersquore building a social security system with a dferent philosophy around dignity and respect, he said, while claiming the UK Government was in a ldquorace to the bottom on tax.While Mackay attempts to create a more progressive Budget, he insists hersquos also trying to remain pro-business as he believes ldquothe best social policy is employment. He dismissed claims of ldquoclass war in his Budget.ldquoIf we donrsquot invest in society and have the necessary safeguards for all then everyone pays for societal failure ndash business and taxpayers pay for this with prisons and unemployment, he says, adding that he believes his Budget presents a ldquopretty good deal.Reformation of council tax is likely to dominate the political discussion soon with plans for cross-party talks to find an alternative. ldquoIf we can find the consensus that could adequately and safety replace it then wersquoll support that, Mackay says. Legislation could be prepared in this Parliament for implementation in the next.Come the end of this Parliament, the country will also be heading towards the time for a review of the ldquofiscal framework set out by the Smith Commission and Scotland Act, which will mean the Government can ask for more powers from Westminster.Mackay admits such an ask wonrsquot be easy as ldquoWestminster concedes nothing without challenge and pressure.

title: david-pratt-just-what-is-going-on-in-haiti
story: THERE is nothing like a coup drsquoetat to bring out the headcase and the hedonist in people.When I first visited Haiti back in , aside from the countryrsquos legions of poor, it seemed almost entirely inhabited by these two species of inidual.The capital Port-au-Prince was in meltdown back then, the cityrsquos ramshackle streets a labyrinth of barricades and blazing tyres, looters, shooters and partygoers.President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was in the process of being deposed from power. In the space of a few weeks, I would watch those same "bouleds" once consumed by violence and littered with corpses turn into one giant carnival as thousands crammed to dance the night away to Haitian and Caribbean music.Everywhere around the national palace that had been Aristidersquos lair of power, giant floats drted by while women in flamingo pink dresses, and voodoo priests, partied against the pure white backdrop of the whitewashed palace facade that dazzled in the nighttime dark like an edice of snow.There are few countries in the world that Irsquove been to quite like Haiti. Even fewer that have seen so much turmoil and destruction. It really does beggar belief that such a place exists an hour-and-a-halfrsquos flight from glittering Miami, and less than three hours from New York City. As the books and experts will attest to, Haiti is the poorest country in the Western hemisphere and the worldrsquos least developed outside of Africa ndash and believe me does it show.At night in the cityrsquos Marche en Fer or Iron Market district, crushing poverty forces sex workers, some little more than children, onto the filthy fire-lit streets.This is a two-tier nation that rises from the slums of Cite Soleil and Saint Martin, where hundreds of thousands cram into reclaimed swampland and cemeteries.So congested is it here that people I met said that ldquosht sleeping is common.With many single cupboard-sized rooms too small to house an entire family at any one time, people have been known to bed down on a rota basis, four hours inside and four hours in the alleyways outside.It might be a short distance as the crow flies in Port-au-Prince, but these teeming, humid slums are a world apart from the cool hills above where the wealthy live in the gated communities of Petionville, with their fine restaurants catering to a very dferent side of Haitian le.Right there in that very juxtaposition Haitirsquos inequality lies encapsulated. A chasm between haves and have-nots that for decades has led to political instability and violence which these past weeks has once again reared up and gripped the country.ldquoAfter each election, we are deeper and deeper in a crisis. People are living day-by-day ... If you donrsquot resolve the situation, yoursquoll have another uprising, warned Jean Clarens Renois, a former journalist and presidential candidate last week as street protests in the country intensied.For the last two weeks now, almost unnoticed by the international media, thousands of Haitians have taken to the streets, asking for US-backed president Jovenel Moise and his government to resign. Writing in the New York Times a few months ago, Jake Johnston, an international associate at the Centre for Economic and Policy Research in Washington and an expert on Haiti, told the story of what sparked the current round of unrest.ldquoIt started with a few keystrokes in a living room in Montreal, he wrote.ldquoGilbert Mirambeau Jr, a Haitian filmmaker and writer, took to Twitter on August  to post a photo of himself, blindfolded, holding a piece of cardboard with a simple question written on it in Haitirsquos Creole: ldquoKot Kob Petwo Karibe a    ndash Where is the Petrocaribe money   As Johnston went on to explain in the article, just a few days after Mirambeaursquos tweet, an informal group of young Haitians organised on social media using the hashtag #PetroCaribeChallenge and since then Haitians from all sectors of society have taken to the streets demanding an answer to Mirambeaursquos original question about what became of the Petrocaribe cash.This vast sum of over  billion is part of low-interest loans provided by Petrocaribe, a Venezuela-led oil-purchasing alliance of Caribbean states that since  was aimed at helping Haitirsquos ailing economy. The funds became crucial emergency money to the country following the devastating earthquake of  that laid waste to swathes of Port-au-Prince and beyond.Since then, the missing cash and whole Petrocaribe affair has become a political cause celebre in a country where ordinary people have seen a % hike in fuel prices and double-digit inflation that has made day-to-day survival extremely challenging for more than % of the population.For decades, ordinary Haitians have felt themselves powerless when confronted with this ongoing legacy of corruption and misgovernment. Presented with few alternative options, iniably they take to the streets as a last resort when trying to change things for the better.With so many locked in the grip of protracted poverty their frustration with the countryrsquos level of corruption is understandable. To take but one example following the  earthquake, it became clear that despite foreign donors pledging more than  billion in aid, less than % of that emergency aid spent in their names went directly to Haitians.I well recall in the wake of the earthquake talking to ordinary Haitians who had lost almost everything. One was a woman called Gladys Pierre, a mother who described that day back in  when just before five orsquoclock the mirrors fell from the walls in her family home and the furniture rose up and flew through the air asthrown by a giant malevolent poltergeist.ldquoA big beam slid, and from the chest up Rachelle was crushed against the wall like a mosquito, and I knew my little girl had died, Gladys told me, her voice trailing off.Unimaginable as the horror of her story was, it didnrsquot stop there. Steeling herself, she continued to tell of how her daughterrsquos semi-crushed skull became a grotesque prop for part of the apartment block wall that remained standing.In the following months, so dangerous were those ruins teetering on their macabre headstone that no-one dared enter to remove Rachellersquos corpse.Like many ordinary Haitians who found themselves now living in one of the tarpaulin cities that became semi-permanent fixtures in Port-au-Prince, Gladys and her husband Joel held out little hope of those in power doing much to improve their lives.ldquoYou only see them in their beautul cars and big jeeps driving up and down but they never stop, never get out of the car, talk to us or even congratulate the women and children on their courage, I recall Joel telling me at the time.And so, in the eyes of many Haitians, this sense of helplessness and frustration remains the way they see their lives and once again anger has boiled over in the country.While president Moise has pledged a crackdown on corruption few see little signs of it. Those who have taken to the streets as part of the protest movement in recent weeks have no clear political leader, but Haiti has a huge diaspora that has harnessed social media in its non-violent #PetroCaribeChallenge, campaigning among a population more than half of whom are under  years old.As ever, though, tensions have risen as government repression against the campaigners has become more unrestrained and brutal. Even in the early stages the signs of this were all too clear when last November armed gangs close to the ruling party, together with corrupt police officers, massacred at least  people just days before protests were due to begin.All this time, US influence ndash official or unofficial ndash has never been far from the surface in Haiti. In the latest case of murky US interference, five heavily-armed Americans were arrested in Port-au-Prince last week along with a Haitian man and two Serbians.The Americans are former Navy Seal officers Christopher Michael Osman and Christopher Mark McKinley, and Marine veteran Kent Leland Kroeker, as well as Talon Ray Burton and Dustin Porte. Burton is a private investigator once employed by the controversial private security company formerly known as Blackwater and the State Departmentrsquos diplomatic security service. Inside their vehicles the Haitian police found six automatic rles, six pistols, two professional drones and three satellite phones, and they were also carrying sets of licence plates.ldquoThey said that they were here on a lsquogovernment mission,rsquo ldquo Miami Herald reporter Jacqueline Charles told US National Public Radio. ldquoThey did not specy which government, but then they did tell the police that ... their boss was going to call their boss.Whether they were mercenaries, ldquogovernment contractors of something , the arrest of the Americans while failing to make global headlines triggered wide speculation about why they were in Haiti, particularly among Moisersquos political foes.The possible explanations range from a desire to protect the central bank or foreign assets to potential attacks on anti-government demonstrators and leaders. According to the Haitian police, the men claimed they were on a ldquogovernment mission when they were pulled over about a block away from the nationrsquos central bank.The US government only subsequently intervened after Haitian prime minister Jean Henry Ceant, speaking on CNN, called the group ldquomercenaries and ldquoterrorists. That they were released from prison and immediately flown back to Miami where they faced no charges has only further fuelled the rumour mill and caused political uproar in Haiti.Pierre Esperance, executive director of the National Human Rights Defence Network in Haiti, blasted the decision by US authorities not to charge the men.ldquoWhat the Haitian government did is grave. It shows that they had something they were looking for. The fact that the US took these people and did not charge them, it shows there was a conspiracy. They didnrsquot want them to go before Haitian justice, he told the Miami Herald.On Friday, the protests on the streets of Port-au-Prince showed no signs of abating. ldquoToday we lock down the country again, opposition leader Schiller Louidor told people who gathered for a funeral of two protesters killed earlier in the week, before they marched on the national palace carrying one of the coffins. ldquoWe are asking for justice. We are going to continue to protest. Jovenel Moise can kill as many people as he wants, he still has to go, said Josef Dicles, a cousin of one of the dead men, Onique Gedeus.And so Haiti is mired in turmoil again and just what the future holds is anybodyrsquos guess. But the mysterious presence of armed Americans and the cancellation of this monthrsquos scheduled carnival in Port-au-Prince certainly bodes ill for this long-suffering nation born out of slavery and still consigned to poverty.

title: chuka-umunna-urges-voters-to-join-movement-for-different-kind-of-politics
story: In a sign that The Independent Groupwill form a fully-fledged parliamentary party, the former Labour MP called for the public to ldquojoin us, and help us forge a new, dferent kind of politics for Britainrsquos future.Our political system is clearly completely broken. Lets change it#ChangePoliticsSIGN UP ## https:t.co NFfmnkIYSUBSCRIBE ## https:t.co TmbLEQp pic TXOTArNmdash Chuka UmunnaFebruary , Mr Umunna, who represents Streatham in south London, is one of eight ex-Labour MPs who have joined forces with three former Tories to form a new group in the Commons.TIG does not have a leader or a detailed policy , however an Opinium poll for The Observer has put the grouprsquos support at % ndash a point ahead of the Lib Dems.Opinium Observer latest political poll: LAB %CON % TIG %LD %  ndash  Febmdash OpiniumFebruary , Meanwhile it has emerged that Sir David Garrard, once one of Labourrsquos biggest donors, is supporting the new group.Writing in the Sunday Mirror, Mr Umunna said the current political system is not working and the established parties are ldquobroken.The former Labour frontbencher said the two main parties had become ldquodominated by extremes, citing factional infighting in his old party and the influence of hardline Brexiteers in the Tories.ldquoThis week we have come together in the national interest, to say lsquoenough is enoughrsquo. We have each put everything on the line to give something new a try. Believe me, it wasnrsquot an easy decision for any of us, Mr Umunna said.ldquoWe donrsquot yet know the destination where the path wersquove taken will lead us. But what me and my Independent Group colleagues are absolutely clear about is that we cannot and must not re-create the old parties with their tribalism and incompetence.ldquoAs we embark on this new chapter, most importantly we want you to help us build a new movement, and wersquore keen to hear from you. Join us, and help us forge a new, dferent kind of politics for Britainrsquos future.TIGrsquos MPs all campaigned for Britain to remain in the EU, while Mr Ummuna has been a prominent supporter of a so-called Peoplersquos Vote.The former shadow business secretary and Labour leadership contender has been described the ldquoobvious candidate to lead TIG in the Commons, where the -strong group equals the Lib Dems in size and outnumbers the DUP by one.There has been continued speculation that more Labour and Tory MPs will quit and potentially join the new group in the coming days and weeks as Brexit comes to a head.The departures already mark the biggest parliamentary schism since the formation of the Social Democratic Party in the s.However, many of TIGrsquos MPs will face a huge challengethey want to hold on to their seats in a future election.Tory breakaway Anna Soubry saw Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and several members of his shadow cabinet stage a rally in her Broxtowe constituency on Saturday.Thank you to everyone who came to our rally in Broxtowe ndash the seat Anna Soubry won by a tiny margin in .Were building a movement to win the next General Election and transform communities across the UK. pic qRzMREyeMUmdash Jeremy CorbynFebruary , Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry said MPs who left Labour had ldquobetrayed their seats and will be defeatedelections are held."Stand tall, stand firm, be proud. We are the future and they are the past. Our future is coming and its coming soon."My message to the brilliant rally in Broxstowe today #ForTheMany pic wbJAUwCrYmdash Emily ThornberryFebruary , Fighting for seats in a general election will require signicant funding, although TIG has already attracted support from major donors who have abandoned the main parties in recent months.Mr Umunna told The Times on Saturday that the group had already raised ldquotens of thousands of pounds from several thousand small donors.And on Sunday Sir David told The Observer: ldquoIrsquove been asked whether I will financially support the new group. I have already done so.The property tycoon, who donated around pound. million to Labour over a period of  years, left the party in protest at the leadershiprsquos handling of the anti-Semitism row.Pimlico Plumbers founder Charlie Mullins, who previously donated to the Tories and then the Lib Dems, indicated to The Times on Saturday that he could also give TIG financial backing.ldquoI believe that any money I put in to the Independent Group will be money well spent because I think Theresa May is destroying the economy, he said.ldquoThis is about our children and grandchildren and the future of this country.

title: crossing borders with your dog after brexit
story: A. The answer to this all depends on whether we leave the EU with or without a deal and when you want to travel.Pet passports wont be valid with a no deal BrexitAt the minute, you are supposed to have a pet passport for your dogtheyrsquore travelling from the UK to the EU and vice versa, although it is my understanding that there are no checks on pets crossing the Republic or Ireland and Northern Ireland border at the minute. Pet passports list the dferent treatments your pet has had and ensures they are microchipped and up to date with their rabies vaccine.Read more: JD Wetherspoon favours more UK products as Brexit moves closerThe passport means your pooch wont have to go into quarantine on arrival.If the UK leaves without a deal, then the rules will change and pet passports issued in the UK would no longer be valid.In this case, pet owners would need to get a health certicate - and the bad news is, this will take at least four months. title: embroidery exhibition at heritage centre
story: The Garioch Heritage Centre in Inverurie will host the Embroiderer#s Guild Lest We Forget embroidery exhibition next week.The free exhibition will run at the centre from Tuesday, February  to Tuesday, March .In  the Guild in conjunction with SSAFAinvited its members to take part in the commemoration of the ending of WW a  years previously by producing one heart.The plan being that each heart would be included in at least one exhibition, ideally, as near to their home location.Thus making unique and thoughtful exhibitions to fulfil the hope of a generation not to be forgotten.Using cloth, thread and textile each heart interprets a unique story of comradeship, bravery, victory or setback told by those ing from the Great War or in their heartfelt letters to those back home.The hearts illustrate to a new generation the men and the animals that accompanied them the unorms worn and medals won the regiments that fought together and the family members fondly remembered the songs that kept their spirits high and the words they wrote to those back home. This is a one-off, not to be missed, opportunity to view the  Scottish Hearts in the North East of Scotland. title: inverurie youth sports foundation appoints hannah as ambassador
story: Inverurie Youth Sports Foundationis delighted to announce the appointment of Hannah Miley OLY as the IYSF ambassador.Hannah will be working alongside the IYSF trustees as they continue to provide financial assistance and support to young people as they strive to achieve their sporting ambitions.The IYSF was established in  to support and promote the future development of youth in sport within the Garioch area. Since its establishment the IYSF has provided assistance to over  athletes, including three para athletes and nine sports clubs organisations across  dferent sports.To date a number of the young sports people supported by the IYSF have gone onto compete at national and international level including the Olympics, Winter Olympics and Commonwealth Games.The IYSF is committed to providing financial support to inidual young persons in sport to ensure that they are able to continue participating in their chosen sport, and to let them take their sporting performance to the next stage and attend national championships and competitions.In addition, the IYSF extends its support to local sports clubs, by providing financial support to a body looking to set up a new club in the local area and providing financial funding to existing clubs which has been used to help towards coaching costs.Willie Lippe, IYSF trustee, said of the recent appointment: “Having Hannah Miley OLY as the IYSF ambassador will be a huge benefit to the IYSF.“Not only will Hannah be a voice of the Inverurie Youth Sports Foundation but as an outstanding sportsperson in her own right, she will be inspirational to young people active in sport today.”In her IYSF ambassador role Hannah presented to Garioch Rugby Club last  Sunday, February , inspiring the next generation of sports people.The IYSF is a charitable foundation that was founded by local entrepreneur Steven Ferguson and his family.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: london fashion week for stylist kelsey
story: A north east hairdresser visited London last week to take part in one of fashion#s most prestigious shows.Senior stylist at Rebecca Carr Hair Salon in Kintore, Ky Catto, was selected as one of the session team for London Fashion Week , which ran from Friday  to Tuesday  February.It is the third time that she has worked at the show, having been selected following a robust audition process at Toni  Guy’s training academy in London in .Ky, from Aberdeen, has been working in the industry since she was a Saturday girl aged  before leaving school at  to take on a hairdressing apprenticeship.She has worked with Rebecca Carr since the salon launched three years ago.Speaking ahead of the event, Ky said: “I have been allocated two designers, DB Berdan and Kalissa, so I have spent time getting a good feel for their inidual styles and getting a better understanding of what they want and need. “Creating styling with designers at LFW is a great experience and working alongside stylists from across the world gives me the opportunity to learn new skills and techniques that improves my offering to my clients.”Ky has travelled to LFW twice with salon owner, Rebecca Carr, and worked with other upcoming designers.Last year, Rebecca worked with fashion designer, Paul Costelloe at the show.She said: “LFW is a brilliant opportunity for any stylist but you are only chosenyou are at the very top of your game so I’m really proud that Ky has been invited back for a third session at the show. “She worked very hard at the audition stage initially and her work over
